issues.title: Move branch comparisons to ALU
issues.body: There are some potential area savings when moving the branch comparisons to the ALU. This will also ease timing on the write back path to the scoreboard/ROB.

issues.title: Extraneous decoder condition
issues.body:
This might seem somewhat perfectionist, but there seems to be an extraneous line in the decoding logic. I am talking about the line 273 in the following excerpt.

https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/3c6e29f23b3559fffe6532326a77a7d741ee3d53/src/decoder.sv#L267-L274

Invalid `OPCODE_OP32` instructions that have their 28th-bit set would not reach the `unique_case` and would not be marked as invalid (as in this process the default assignment is `illegal_instr = 1'b0`).

issues.title: [Feature] A-Extension Support
issues.body:
This issue targets the long needed atomic memory support. 

## Tasks

- [x] Add support to execute AMOs without any of the ordering bits set
- [ ] Add support for aq and rl bits
- [x] Work on adding LR and SC instructions

## Overview

General there are 4 cases:

**acquire semantic**: If the `aq` bit is set, then no later memory operations in this RISC-V hart can be observed to take place before the AMO.
-> block issue until the atomic memory operation is resolved, wait on commit signal, flush cache, do AMO, write back

**release semantic**: If the `rl` bit is set, then other RISC-V harts will not observe the AMO before memory accesses preceding the AMO in this RISC-V hart.
-> block issue until no more outstanding loads (trivially met as the load unit will implicitly synchronize, structural hazard) or stores (wait for store buffer to drain), wait on AMO commit, flush cache, do AMO, write-back

**sequentially consistent**: If both the `aq` and `rl` bits are set, the atomic memory operation is sequentially consistent and cannot be observed to happen before any earlier memory operations or after any later memory operations in the same RISC-V hart, and can only be observed by any other hart in the same global order of all sequentially consistent atomic memory operations to the same address domain.
-> block issue until no more outstanding loads or stores, issue atomic, wait on commit signal, block issue until atomic comited, flush dcache, do amo, write-back

**unordered**: aq and rl not set -> just issue -> wait for amo_commit -> flush dcache -> do AMO -> write back AMO

## Details

- **Decoder** (`decoder.sv`): The atomic instruction needs to be properly decoded. Most of the operations are there but this needs some further checking (especially if all parameters are set properly and illegal instructions are thrown in case of an illegal instruction with the `OPCODE_AMO`).
Decoder will also need to block the decoding of any subsequent instructions in case the instruction requires release, acquire or sequential consistency. There is already an `amo_commit_i` signal which indicates that the atomic memory operation finished. If we block the issue stage we need to un-block it if the controller wants to flush.

- **LSU - Data Cache** (`lsu.sv`, `nbdcache.sv`, `cache_ctrl.sv`): Those units will require the biggest amount of changes. Basically every atomic instruction should be treated as a load (because even the stores will return something: success or not). So we need to route those instructions similar to a load. The load unit will interface the dcache with an additional signal `amo_t amo_op_o` indicating whether the current operation is atomic (and which operation) or a regular load.
In case it is an atomic operation the `cache_ctrl ` FSM will enter a new state saving all information (address, op to perform, etc.) and wait for the `amo_commit_i` signal to go high or for `amo_flush_i` to go high. If the latter happens it will return to the idle state. If the `amo_commit_i` signal goes high the cache controller should flush the data cache and issue a new transaction on the bypass signal once the flush is done.
Here we need to differentiate between LR/SC and the AMO OPs. LR/SC will need to use the AXI Lock infrastructure (see AXI Interface specification) to place a reservation (we will need to adapt the testbench for that) while the AMO OPs can retrieve the data process it locally with the AMO ALU. In every case the atomic memory operations will return some result on the `amo_result_o` signal together with a high `amo_valid_o`. Both signals go to the commit stage.
> One further thing which needs a fix is to increase the the width of the dirty SRAM so that it holds a dirty bit per byte. The flush/cache line write-back logic needs to set the corresponding `wstrb` bits. That is because Ariane does not support cache-coherency at the moment and we need to explicitly take care of write-sequentialisation. 

- **Commit Stage** (`commit_stage.sv`): This unit will need to look at the retiring instruction and see that it is an atomic instruction. If it is an atomic instruction the commit stage will assert the `amo_comit` signal for one cycle and block committing new instructions until the `amo_valid_o` is high and indicating a successful atomic memory operation. It will commit the result into the register file. And continue comiting new instructions.

Feel free to check-back, clarify, hack-away.

issues.title: Should debug_set_pc_i set flush_icache (how else do we inform a new program is loaded ?)
Cache coherence during a flush
issues.body:
There are some issues with the cache control:
- The cache control block should not serve a request if the cache is being flushed.
- A flush should reinitialize the cache, so the next requests are fetched from memory.

issues.title: Single-stepping bug ?
issues.body: I am detecting symptoms of a problem with single-stepping a program which works fine when run in one go. The symptom is that normal instructions work but branch and jump instructions always keep going to the next instruction in line regardless. If this is a true bug, can you confirm or suggest where in the code I should look to diagnose the problem?

issues.title: Load requests not being killed after a flush
issues.body:
A high `kill_req_i` should kill the load requests for the `cache_ctrl` no matter what state it is currently in. In the current version, some states of `cache_ctrl` are not sensible to `kill_req_i`.

In my case, the request was not killed and a speculative load that was issued before a flush wrote the scoreboard after the flush, but with a wrong pre-flush transaction id.

issues.title: Forwarding of FP registers
issues.body:
There is a potential problem with the forwarding logic of floating point registers.

https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/8620f41ea1db93c7883844011092147a23cabab3/src/scoreboard.sv#L217-L220

In the excerpt above, it is the destination register of `mem_q[i]` that is being forwarded as source register of `issue_instr_o`. Because of this, I think the correct check should be `is_rd_fpr(mem_q[i].sbe.op) == is_rs1_fpr(issue_instr_o.op)` instead. There are more cases of this throughout the scoreboard.

---

Also, in `is_rd_fpr` (and `is_rs2_fpr`), shouldn't the test below go up to `[FLD:FLB]` instead of stopping at `FLW`?

https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/8620f41ea1db93c7883844011092147a23cabab3/include/ariane_pkg.sv#L253-L256

```
cd tmp/riscv-tests

cd build
make
cd ../../..

issues.title: PTW protocol violation if during pipeline flush
issues.body:
The PTW has an illegal state in which it can violate the `req`, `gnt` protocol (from `PTE_LOOKUP` to `IDLE` during flush).

https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/838b04a96c45cee81ce658492baf74f117357dd2/src/ptw.sv#L331-L338

Example execution trace:

```
1127755000     112766 U 0000000000005fce 0 00000013 nop                                 
1127765000     112767 U 0000000000005fd0 0 00ee579b srliw            a5, t3, 0xe         x15 =0000000000000000 t3  :0000000000000000
1127775000     112768 U 0000000000005fd4 0 0000100f fence.i                             
1132915000     113282 U 0000000000005fd8 0 40755b3b sraw             s6, a0, t2          x22 =ffffffffffffffff a0  :ffffffffffffffff t2  :0000000000000000
1132925000     113283 U 0000000000005fdc 0 12000073 sfence.vma                          
1133245000     113315 U 0000000000005fe0 0 00000000 INVALID                             
Exception @1133245000, PC: 0000000000005fe0, Cause: Instruction Page Fault, 
tval: 0000000000005fe0
```

issues.title: MSTATUS.MIE is written unexpectedly when programming SSTATUS
issues.body: `MSTATUS.MIE` is enabled first, however, the value is overwritten when `SSTATUS` is programmed. SSTATUS[3] is a WPRI field, hardware should ignore this write and preserve the current value.

issues.title: sfence.vma not treated as an illegal instruction in S (TVM=1) and U-Mode
issues.body:
In this case, sfence.vma is executed in U mode, spike treats it as an illegal instruction but RTL processed it without reporting any exception.

RTL log:
```
 246785000      24669 U 0000000000005070 0 12000073 sfence.vma                          
 246975000      24688 U 0000000000005074 0 0018cd33 xor              s10, a7, ra         x26 =00000000d783bfc1 a7  :00000000d783bfc1 ra  :0000000000000000
```
Spike log:
```
core   0: 0x0000000000005070 (0x12000073) sfence.vma (args unknown)
core   0: exception trap_illegal_instruction, epc 0x0000000000005070
```

Spike implementation: (`sfence.vma` can only be executed in M mode or S mode depending on TVM setting)

https://github.com/riscv/riscv-isa-sim/blob/2cd60b277e909a5599ca48e4561cbfbc61460186/riscv/insns/sfence_vma.h#L1

issues.title: [DCache] Back to back Store instruction corrupt data cache
issues.body:
Here's the load/store instruction that access PA `'h800c6020` ~` 'h800c6027`. The load data `00000000fffe0000` of the last instruction is incorrect.
```
 217541500     217532  000000000001ceee 0 ffceb123 sd               t3, -30(t4)         t3  :0000000080000000 t4  :00000000000c603e VA: 00000000000c6020 PA: 00000000800c6020
 517840500     517831  000000000004092e 0 ff05b683 ld               a3, -16(a1)         x13 =0000000080000000 a1  :00000000000c6030 VA: 00000000000c6020 PA: 00000000800c6020
 735718500     735709  000000000005adb8 0 e436c683 lbu              a3, -445(a3)        x13 =0000000000000000 a3  :00000000000c61e1 VA: 00000000000c6024 PA: 00000000800c6024
 884744500     884735  000000000006c5e0 0 00f5e503 lwu              a0, 15(a1)          x10 =00000000fffe0000 a1  :00000000000c6015 VA: 00000000000c6024 PA: 00000000800c6024
```
Mismatch:
```
ERROR: Mismatch: Instr[105239] Spike reg[10] = 0000000000000000 RTL reg[10] = 00000000fffe0000
Spike instruction   :  lwu     a0, 15(a1)
RTL sim instruction :   lwu              a0, 15(a1)          
ERROR: Mismatch: Instr[105856] Spike reg[22] = 000000000000fffe RTL reg[22] = 0000000000000000
Spike instruction   :  lhu     s6, -106(a3)
RTL sim instruction :   lhu              s6, -106(a3)        
ERROR: Mismatch: Instr[162156] Spike reg[13] = 00000000fffe0000 RTL reg[13] = 0000000000000000
Spike instruction   :  lwu     a3, -369(s6)
RTL sim instruction :   lwu              a3, -369(s6)

Spike instruction   :  mulh    s6, a3, t3
RTL sim instruction :   mulh             s6, a3, t3         
```
Looks like these two back-to-back store messed up the cache.
```

 712003500     711994  0000000000058002 0 f8d51723 sh               a3, -114(a0)        a3  :fffffffffffffffe a0  :00000000000d0098 VA: 00000000000d0026 PA: 00000000800d0026

issues.title: FPGA Synthesis Timing issues
issues.body:
Hello, 

Not sure, since there are no forums: I'm trying to synthesize it for an FPGA Xilinx xcvu9p* family,  I created a design block that connects the three AXI, to access brams, the goal it is evaluate if I can synthesize it for >= 200Mhz of frequency. 

However I'm facing a barrage of timing issues, that weren't expected, for things like, input and output pads:
```
...
        input  logic                           test_en_i,     // enable all clock gates for testing
        // CPU Control Signals
        input  logic                           fetch_enable_i,
        // Core ID, Cluster ID and boot address are considered more or less static
        //input  logic [63:0]                    boot_addr_i,
        input  logic [ 3:0]                    core_id_i,
        input  logic [ 5:0]                    cluster_id_i,
        input  logic                           flush_req_i,
        output logic                           flushing_o,
        // Interrupt inputs
        input  logic [1:0]                     irq_i,        // level sensitive IR lines, mip & sip
        input  logic                           ipi_i,        // inter-processor interrupts
        output logic                           sec_lvl_o,    // current privilege level oot
        // Timer facilities
        input  logic [63:0]                    time_i,        // global time (most probably coming from an RTC)
        input  logic                           time_irq_i,    // timer interrupt in
        // Debug Interface
        input  logic                           debug_req_i,
        output logic                           debug_gnt_o,
        output logic                           debug_rvalid_o,
        input  logic [15:0]                    debug_addr_i,
        input  logic                           debug_we_i,
        input  logic [63:0]                    debug_wdata_i,
        output logic [63:0]                    debug_rdata_o,
        output logic                           debug_halted_o,
        input  logic                           debug_halt_i,
        input  logic                           debug_resume_i,
 ...
```
The boot address I fixed:
```
                .boot_addr_i(64'h8000_0000),  
```
The goal here is synthesize it on an FPGA, to prove that this same core can be used on FPGA, ... I understand that it looks reverse path, but yes, on ASIC I'm sure on what to do, and I got the timing closure on ASIC flow. However in FPGA on Vivado it is being quite cumbersome, what have I forgot to do or add?

By the way I had to made a slight change in the code to use synchronous reset, otherwise, I was getting nowhere with timing in the FPGA. So I created a serieis of ifdefs to choose accoridng with a  MACRO modifier what to use:
```
ifdef PULP_FPGA_EMUL
always @(posedge clk) 
else
always @(posedge clk or negedge rstn)
endif
```
I'm using the PULP_FGPA_EMUL, since I had to enable it to synthesize it for FPGAs.

I have an oscillator of 300Mhz, that gets into a PLL,  and generates a 200 and 250 Mhz signals, that are the ones I'm using to feed the system.

SDC/XDC clock constraints:
```
create_clock -period 3.333 [get_ports clk_in1_p]
set_input_jitter [get_clocks -of_objects [get_ports clk_in1_p]] 0.033330000000000005

set_property PHASESHIFT_MODE LATENCY [get_cells -hierarchical *adv*]

//set the reset in a false path to prevent the timing report to goes bananas on the reset signals
set_false_path -to [get_pins -hier *cdc_to*/D].
```
There is a forum to discuss design issues like this one?

Regards,
Vitorio.

issues.title: [Enhancement] Reduce number of dcache read ports to 2

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Enhancement
labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body: The PTW currently has an exclusive readport into the dcache. This is overprovisioning, as PTWs should not occur frequently. Sharing the read port with the load unit should lead to lower HW complexity and better timing in the dcache.

issues.title: [Enhancement] Micro TLB + Multilevel TLB

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Enhancement
labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

labels.name: Status:New
labels.description: Newly created issue, nobody has looked at it yet.

issues.body: Splitting the TLB into a micro TLB with 4 entries and a larger (possibly multilevel) TLB can improve the timing on the cache tag comparison paths.

issues.title: [Enhancement] Remove separate scoreboard write port for Mult/Div
issues.body: Share the Mult/Div scoreboard writeback port with the ALU port. This frees up an additional writeback port for the load unit.

issues.title: [Enhancement] Optimize LSU return path into the scoreboard
issues.body: The return path of the LSU and the LSU arbiter are on a critical path. Provisioning separate write ports into the scoreboard would allow to remove the LSU arbiter. This should be feasible with moderate overhead if we share the writeback ports between ALU and Mult/Div (see  #118).

issues.title: [Enhancement] Trace log needs improving
issues.body:
ariane produces a tracelog trace_core_00_0.dasm, which may be converted to trace_core_00_0.dis using spike-dasm. I have found that the trace log disagrees with the disassembled binary in the sense that compressed instructions are shown post conversion:

disassembly:
```
0000000040000382 <_init>:
    40000382:   00001517                auipc   a0,0x1
    40000386:   2c650513                addi    a0,a0,710 # 40001648 <_bss>
    4000038a:   00001617                auipc   a2,0x1
    4000038e:   30e60613                addi    a2,a2,782 # 40001698 <_end>
    40000392:   1101                    addi    sp,sp,-32
    40000394:   8e09                    sub     a2,a2,a0
```
trace log:
```
88 0x40000382 M (0x00001517) auipc   a0, 0x1
89 0x40000386 M (0x2c650513) addi    a0, a0, 710
90 0x4000038a M (0x00001617) auipc   a2, 0x1
91 0x4000038e M (0x30e60613) addi    a2, a2, 782
92 0x40000392 M (0xfe010113) addi    sp, sp, -32
93 0x40000394 M (0x40a60633) sub     a2, a2, a0
```
also sometimes the expanded instruction is < 0xFFFF leading to an ambiguity
for poor humans to get confused by:

    40000068:   6319                    lui     t1,0x6
 
becomes:

                  65 0x40000068 M (0x00006337) lui     t1, 0x6

In addition the PC counter log appears misaligned to those not in the know
because 32-bit instructions are apparently fetched with a PC increment of 2.

issues.title: Highest bits in Sv39
issues.body:
The spec says:

  Load and store effective addresses, which are 64 bits, must have bits 63–39 
  all equal to bit 38, or else a page-fault exception will occur.

The code says:
```
  // check that all bits in the address >= 39 are equal
  if (!((&lsu_ctrl.vaddr[63:39]) == 1'b1 || (|lsu_ctrl.vaddr[63:39]) == 1'b0)) ...
```
So then the 39 in the code should be 38?

Jan

issues.title: fpga Makefile target not robust
issues.body:
Top-level Ariane Makefile has a target called fpga. Top-level Ariane also has a subdirectory called fpga. Therefore, if the directory is newer than any of the dependencies, fpga target will not be built even if it needs to be.

Solution: rename fpga target or perhaps making it .PHONY might solve the problem
Workaround: make fpga -B

issues.title: Data cache on FPGA design not working?
issues.body:
Hi,

When I run the following code on Ariane on Verilator I get a CPI of 1.5:

    for(int i = 0; i < 10000; i++)
      asm volatile ("ld %0, 0(%1)" : "=r"(dummy2) : "r"(&dummy));

I would expect that with a branch that is predictable and a load that always hits the dcache, the 
CPI would be closer to one but it is a lot better than when I run the same code (compiled
with -O) on the Genesys 2 board. Then I get a CPI of 11.2! It seems that the data cache
is not used. Any idea what is wrong? The bitfile on https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/releases
gives the same result.

This loop (without dcache accesses) gives a CPI of 1.3 on Verilator and a CPI of 2.4 on the FPGA:

    for(int i = 0; i < 10000; i++)
      asm volatile("");

Regards,
Jan

issues.title: Weird gdb behaviour
issues.body:
When the gdb/openocd debugger stops at a breakpoint, register A0 is always zero. If the programmer debugs any expression involving A0 at that point, the debugger may perform an illegal access. Since A0 is the first function parameter, this is a highly likely scenario if it contains a pointer. A workaround of adding a dummy first parameter in the source code to each function that might be stopped in the debugger fixes the problem. Single stepping involving instructions that read A0 gives the expected (non zero) answer. This is suggestive to me that reporting temporary registers used in the debugger service ROM is incorrect, or perhaps an API incompatibility in openocd.

Open On-Chip Debugger 0.10.0+dev-00778-g425c0a7 (2019-01-15-17:51)
GNU gdb (GDB) 8.0.50.20170724-git
ariane development branch (based on master branch)

issues.title: PLIC Enhancements

issues.title: Add AMO messaging capabilities to OpenPiton AXI Cache adapters
Follow up on DDR Linux Reporting Issue
Fix 32 Bit addressing in CLINT
Ariane 4.1.0 release performance
issues.body:
The L1 is looking a lot better now, the booting is twice as quick (excluding the glacial bootrom phase).

However, a curious thing is now observed:

bare metal:

working_set = 0KB, 92207 instructions, 119933 cycles, CPI = 1.300 (now agrees with simulation)
working_set = 4KB, 92207 instructions, 129334 cycles, CPI = 1.402
working_set = 8KB, 92207 instructions, 516094 cycles, CPI = 5.597
working_set = 16KB, 92207 instructions, 516094 cycles, CPI = 5.597
working_set = 32KB, 92207 instructions, 516095 cycles, CPI = 5.597
working_set = 64KB, 92207 instructions, 516095 cycles, CPI = 5.597

all as expected.

Linux:

$ time /cachetest.elf
working_set =  0KB, 438158 instructions, 892896 cycles, CPI = 2.037840
working_set =  4KB, 436607 instructions, 880156 cycles, CPI = 2.015900
working_set =  8KB, 439825 instructions, 905571 cycles, CPI = 2.058935
working_set = 16KB, 435863 instructions, 865359 cycles, CPI = 1.985392
working_set = 32KB, 439919 instructions, 916115 cycles, CPI = 2.082463
working_set = 64KB, 435860 instructions, 875596 cycles, CPI = 2.008893
real	0m 0.45s
user	0m 0.32s
sys	0m 0.13s

which gives the conclusion that user mode under Linux is (worst case) 7.5 times slower than bare metal (?).

This implies that the combined overheads of virtual memory, timer interrupts, polling peripherals, and task switching is huge and totally swamps the expected L1 gains. 

Not in any way trying to diminish the achievement so far, but it does seem to have moved the bottleneck elsewhere. However I would expect the new PLIC to help reduce polling overheads for a start.

issues.title: A problem with FCMP instructions
issues.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/56850968-2d459580-693c-11e9-922b-6385215fb462.png)


For FCMP instructions, the ```rd``` field points to a integer register. As a result, in ```commit_stage.sv```:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/56850974-37679400-693c-11e9-9182-b82e4d54f013.png)


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/56850981-42babf80-693c-11e9-999d-fc5d3cec038b.png)


We will have ```is_rd_fpr(commit_instr_i[0].op) == 0``` and ```is_rd_fpr(commit_instr_i[1].op) == 0```, so we get ```we_fpr_o[1:0] = 2'b00```, which leads to ```commit_stage.dirty_fp_state_o = 0```. 

In csr_regfile, we have ```dirty_fp_state_i = 0```.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/56850999-8d3c3c00-693c-11e9-8bb8-f6173c0993c5.png)
So mstatus_d.fs will not be set to ```Dirty```. However, we should set mstatus_d.fs to Dirty, since the FCMP instructions also change the value of ```CSR_FFLAGS```.

issues.title: The FPU seems not fully IEEE 754-2008 compliant
issues.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/56851315-2ae53a80-6940-11e9-961c-83c939533cff.png)

From my understanding, when a floating-point operation gets a +inf/-inf result, the value that should be stored in floating-point register (fpr) is influenced by the rounding mode. Let's think about single-precision floating-point number. If the result is +inf and the rounding mode is ```roundTowardNegative``` or ```roundTowardZero```, then we should write 0x7f7f_ffff into a fpr. If the result is -inf and the rounding mode is ```roundTowardPositive``` or ```roundTowardZero```, then we should write 0xff7f_ffff into a fpr. 

However, in fpnew_fma.sv, when we get a +inf/-inf result, you just set ```special_result``` to 0x7f80_0000 or 0xff80_0000:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/56851411-a5628a00-6941-11e9-8731-f5b6ec3dde99.png)

It seems that the FPU doesn't fully follow the IEEE 754-2008. The same issue might also exist in other FPU modules, as I have only read the source codes of the FMA module.

Is it a must for us to design a hardware FPU that fully follows the IEEE 754-2008?

issues.title: Divider Rounding Issues

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Status:Wont-fix
labels.description: Issue will not be fixed

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

issues.body:
> There is still work to do on sub-normalised divides but this is repeatable and unrelated. For example 2.350988561514729E-38 / 2 => 0. (it should give 1.175494350822288E-38, a subnormal value)

Hello, thanks for your inputs.
Indeed we are aware of bugs in the FP divider and square-root unit, however this one I haven't seen yet (see end of post for more thoughts on the bug).
The div/sqrt unit we currently have is not very configurable and the code is quite convoluted, so we are hoping to replace it with something more flexible (and IEEE compliant) soon. Hence a bugfix for the current div/sqrt is not a high priority at this time.

Long-winded addendum
The result value you list is correct (under default rounding), however it's actually encoded as the smallest normal FP32 value 0x00800000. The infinitely precise result lies exactly between this result and the largest subnormal FP32 value.
The div/sqrt bugs we've seen so far concern off-by-one-ulp because of wrong rounding. What's possibly happening here seems to be that the mantissa is correctly rounded from all-ones (from the infinitely precise, subnormal result) up to all-zeroes, however the overflow produced from rounding doesn't seem to be added onto the (subnormal = 0) exponent. This leads to the zero result.
I don't know whether this bug is contained to this subnormal/normal border case, but it might be possible that mantissa overflows from rounding in general are buggy.

issues.title: csr_we & exception
issues.body:
Hi,

I have the following scenario
U-mode => exception => exception handler in S-mode (starts with "csrrw t0, sscratch, t0") => interrupt => M-mode => back to S-mode exception handler
The csrrw instruction is executed twice: once every time the program goes in S-mode, because the epc value is in both cases set to the beginning of the Smode exception handler.
This results in a corrupted t0 and sscratch once the S trap handler continues.

I noticed that csr operations are not disabled when ex_i.valid=1.
This behaviour seem also to be different from what happens with the normal registers: write operations are filtered out in case of exceptions.

What's the reason for that?
Do you think this might be a problem in Ariane?

This has been noticed using version bsc-3-10-18.


Regards,
Max

issues.title: Does ariane support Machine mode external interrupt?
issues.body:
In https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/master/src/csr_regfile.sv#L490-L493:
```

riscv::CSR_MIE: begin
                    mask = riscv::MIP_SSIP | riscv::MIP_STIP | riscv::MIP_SEIP | riscv::MIP_MSIP | riscv::MIP_MTIP;
                    mie_d = (mie_q & ~mask) | (csr_wdata & mask); // we only support supervisor and M-mode interrupts
                end

```

It seems that mie_q[MIP_MEIP] (mie_q[11]) is always set to 0.

issues.title: WFI
issues.body:
Hi,

I have a problem using the WFI instruction with Ariane 4.2.

My asm code looks like this
```
...
 200096a:	10500073          	wfi
 200096e:	0001                	nop
 2000970:	0001                	nop
 2000972:	0001                	nop
 2000974:	0001                	nop
 2000976:	0001                	nop
 2000978:	c09d                	beqz	s1,200099e <test+0xd4>
 200097a:	00144783          	lbu	a5,1(s0)
 ...
```

and this is the corresponding waveform
![wfi_fail](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25659164/60685610-47ec3b80-9ea4-11e9-84a3-2eaa0d340df0.png)

The 7 instructions after the WFI command has reached the csr_regfile are executed (even if the interrupt has not yet arrived). This results in the LBU instruction being executed, even if I would have expected it to be run after the reception of the irq (it reads data written by the peripheral generating the interrupt).

Is this the way Ariane is expected to work?
I didn't see this behaviour with the Ariane core released last October.

An obvious workaround for me is to add 7 NOPs after WFI.

issues.title: MMU/TLB/SFENCE.VMA in Ariane 4.2
issues.body:
Dear PULP team,

While testing the microkernel on Ariane v4.2 we are experiencing some weird behaviour which seems to be connected with the MMU/TLB/SFENCE implementation.
It happens very often that the testsuite (which should be pretty stable, since it has been successfully used with other platforms) crashes in a way that it is not possible to easily determine the exception cause.
By analyzing the few useful information we’ve been able to collect (we’ve seen an INSTR_PAGE_FAULT in a handful of failing tests), we’ve made some experiments and discovered that changing the code from

write satp
sfence.vma

to

sfence.vma
sfence.vma
write satp
sfence.vma
sfence.vma

makes the tests much more stable.

We’ve also tried 

sfence.vma
write satp

as suggested in the riscv privilege specs v1.10 (page 58) but this caused even more issues than the original version.

Have you already encountered such situations? Maybe you already have some improvements in this direction which might be useful in our case?


Thanks and best regards,
Max

issues.title: Architecturally visible exception in mispredicted branch

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Status:Resolved
labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

issues.body:
Hi,

We observe a `ret` instruction where the return address is wrongly predicted as `0x0` by the return address stack. The speculative execution at `0x0` triggers an `INSTRUCTION_PAGE_FAULT`, since `0x0` is not mapped. However, since it is mispredicted, it should be flushed once the misprection is detected. Yet, we see the exception occur nonetheless.

We've included a buffer that tracks some internal signals of the frontend:
<details><summary>Frontend Buffer</summary>

| Time | icache\_dreq\_o\.vaddr | priv\_lvl | Instr\[0\] | Instr\[1\] | Active Signals                                                                                                               |
|------|------------------------|-----------|------------|------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 0    | 0xffffffff810a0000     | S         | 0x0        | 0x0        | \-                                                                                                                    |
| \-1  | 0x2c430                | U         | 0x0        | 0x0        | \-                                                                                                                    |
| \-2  | 0x2c42c                | U         | 0x87aad3df | 0x0        | \-                                                                                                                    |
| \-3  | 0x2c42a                | U         | 0xd3dfe0ef | 0x87aa     | if\_ready, icache\_dreq\_o\.kill\_s2, bp\_valid, instr\_valid\[0\], instr\_valid\[1\], rvi\_call\[0\], rvi\_jump\[0\] |
| \-4  | 0x2d6f4                | U         | 0xe0ef4501 | 0x0        | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\]                                                                                          |
| \-5  | 0x2d6f0                | U         | 0x45814601 | 0x4581     | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\], instr\_valid\[1\]                                                                       |
| \-6  | 0x2d6ec                | U         | 0xfec42783 | 0x86be     | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\], instr\_valid\[1\]                                                                       |
| \-7  | 0x2d6e8                | U         | 0x2783     | 0x0        | if\_ready                                                                                                             |
| \-8  | 0x2d6e4                | U         | 0x71398082 | 0x7139     | if\_ready, rvc\_return\[0\]                                                                                           |
| \-9  | 0x2d6e2                | U         | 0x71398082 | 0x7139     | if\_ready, rvc\_return\[0\]                                                                                           |
| \-10 | 0x4                    | U         | 0x71398082 | 0x7139     | icache\_dreq\_o\.kill\_s1, icache\_dreq\_o\.kill\_s2, is\_mispredict, flush\_i, rvc\_return\[0\]                      |
| \-11 | 0x0                    | U         | 0x71398082 | 0x7139     | icache\_dreq\_o\.kill\_s2, bp\_valid, instr\_valid\[0\], instr\_valid\[1\], rvc\_return\[0\]                          |
| \-12 | 0x2d764                | U         | 0x61217442 | 0x6121     | instr\_valid\[0\], instr\_valid\[1\]                                                                                  |
| \-13 | 0x2d760                | U         | 0x61217442 | 0x6121     | if\_ready                                                                                                             |
| \-14 | 0x2d75c                | U         | 0x61217442 | 0x6121     | \-                                                                                                                    |
| \-15 | 0x2d764                | U         | 0x61217442 | 0x6121     | icache\_dreq\_o\.kill\_s1, icache\_dreq\_o\.kill\_s2, replay, instr\_valid\[0\], instr\_valid\[1\]                    |
| \-16 | 0x2d760                | U         | 0x70e2853e | 0x70e2     | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\], instr\_valid\[1\]                                                                       |
| \-17 | 0x2d75c                | U         | 0xf8e7d8e3 | 0x4781     | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\], instr\_valid\[1\], rvi\_branch\[0\]                                                     |
| \-18 | 0x2d758                | U         | 0x07800793 | 0x0        | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\]                                                                                          |
| \-19 | 0x2d754                | U         | 0x0007871b | 0x0        | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\]                                                                                          |
| \-20 | 0x2d750                | U         | 0xfec42783 | 0x0        | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\]                                                                                          |
| \-21 | 0x2d74c                | U         | 0xfec42783 | 0x0        | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\]                                                                                          |
| \-22 | 0x2d748                | U         | 0x26232785 | 0x0        | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\]                                                                                          |
| \-23 | 0x2d744                | U         | 0xfec42783 | 0x0        | if\_ready, instr\_valid\[0\]                                                                                          |


</details>

The contents get updated with each new `fetch_address` while we are in or come from u-mode. It can be seen that `0x0` is predicted (at `Time = -11`) but discarded (`is_mispredict`) in the following step. The `0x0` instruction fetch makes it's way through the I$ to the PTW, where the invalid PTE is found, the exception created (`ptw.sv:222`) and eventually - unexpectedly - retired. We would have expected that it got flushed before retirement.

With best regards,
Nils

issues.body:
In mmu.sv:
![图片](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/63220312-165ed380-c1b7-11e9-8ea7-e77193aebc29.png)
![图片](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/63220316-24acef80-c1b7-11e9-9d61-fd0a66a294c6.png)
Is it better to generate a ```INSTR_ACCESS_FAULT``` exception in this situation ?

But I also find that in instr_queue.sv, ```INSTR_ACCESS_FAULT``` and ```INSTR_PAGE_FAULT``` are both converted to ```INSTR_PAGE_FAULT```:
![图片](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/63220328-6e95d580-c1b7-11e9-8ca0-b77cdd969485.png)
What will the OS do when it meets ```INSTR_ACCESS_FAULT``` and ```INSTR_PAGE_FAULT```? If the OS treats them the same way, it doesn't matter.

issues.title: Memory preloading not working

issues.title: Using GDB to debug `rv64ui-v-add` on FPGA
issues.body:
I've loaded a bitstream for Ariane onto my FPGA. It seems to be working fine -- I'm able to boot Linux using an SD card.

I want to run some of the `riscv-tests`. In particular, I've compiled `rv64ui-v-add`. At first, everything seems OK; we start at PC = 0x8000_0000:

```
(gdb) load
Loading section .text.init, size 0x174 lma 0x80000000
Loading section .tohost, size 0x48 lma 0x80001000
Loading section .text, size 0xfac lma 0x80002000
Loading section .rodata.str1.8, size 0x1e0 lma 0x80002fb0
Start address 0x80000000, load size 4936
Transfer rate: 3 KB/sec, 1234 bytes/write.
(gdb) where
#0  _start ()
	at /home/jeff/riscv/riscv-tools/riscv-tests/isa/../env/v/entry.S:19
(gdb) x/i 0x80000000
=> 0x80000000 <_start>:    j    0x8000000c <handle_reset>
```

This squares with `rv64ui-v-add.dump`:

```
Disassembly of section .text.init:

0000000080000000 <_start>:
	80000000:   00c0006f            	j   	8000000c <handle_reset>

0000000080000004 <nmi_vector>:
	80000004:   2600206f            	j   	80002264 <wtf>

0000000080000008 <trap_vector>:
	80000008:   25c0206f            	j   	80002264 <wtf>

000000008000000c <handle_reset>:
	8000000c:   00000297            	auipc   t0,0x0
	80000010:   ffc28293            	addi	t0,t0,-4 # 80000008 <trap_vector>
``` 

But then if I try to place a breakpoint at `handle_reset` and do `(gdb) continue`, GDB never regains control. No breakpoint is ever triggered. I've tried placing breakpoints elsewhere in the program, but the result is always the same.

If, on the other hand, I do `(gdb) step` from the very beginning, I get the following result, where it appears to regain control at a nonsensical PC value:

```
(gdb) where
#0  _start () at /home/jeff/riscv/riscv-tools/riscv-tests/isa/../env/v/entry.S:19
(gdb) x/i 0x80000000
=> 0x80000000 <_start>:    j    0x8000000c <handle_reset>
(gdb) step
0xffffffffffe000cc in ?? ()
(gdb) where
#0  0xffffffffffe000cc in ?? ()
Backtrace stopped: previous frame identical to this frame (corrupt stack?)
```

I suspect I must be misunderstanding some aspect of the `*.S` file compilations. Why isn't GDB able to reliably step through these tests?

EDIT: Just to clarify, I am not running Linux while I'm debugging the `riscv-tests`. I'm trying to run and inspect `rv64ui-v-add` on bare metal.

issues.body:
Hi,

in csr_regfile.sv I see this condition is used to exit from WFI
```        
if (|mip_q || debug_req_i || irq_i[1]) begin
            wfi_d = 1'b0;
```
I don't understand why the core should be waken up in case of a pending interrupt, even if it has not been enabled via MIE, or in case of an external irq for supervisor mode, again unmasked.
In case an interrupt is received, the code will continue its execution but might not enter the ISR.

issues.title: Return-address stack prediction hints
issues.body:
Could you please comment on this change request?
https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/pull/318/files

Looking at table 2.1 in the user level specs v2.2 a return (pop) should happen when rs1=(x1 or x5) and rd != rs1, but in your code
`((instr_i[11:7] == 5'd1) | instr_i[11:7] == 5'd5)`
seems like you're using rd=(x1 or x5) instead, being rd = instr[11:7] according to the specs.

issues.title: Confused about load_unit.sv
issues.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18757974/65846467-72994380-e370-11e9-909b-6d0cf28d0e95.png)

I am confused about the logic here.
If a load instruction meets an exception(ex_i.valid = 1), and there is a new load instruction in lsu_bypass(valid_i = 1), it seems that the value of pop_ld_o doesn't matter. Because the early load instruction that has an exception will flush the whole pipeline and make the cpu enter the exception handler. So we don't have to care about whether we should delete the later load instruction from lsu_bypass.

In my unix world i am able to clone the ariane github repository using the command

git clone https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane.git

Code
https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/f66b2f19377b3c69409d53f85bb938e187dde411/fpga/scripts/run.tcl#L42
which cause empty match in FPGA flow
```bash
WARNING:` [Vivado 12-818] No files matched '*../src/common_cells/include/common_cells/registers.svh'
# set file_obj [get_files -of_objects [get_filesets sources_1] [list "*$file" "*$registers"]]
# set_property -dict { file_type {Verilog Header} is_global_include 1} -objects $file_obj
# update_compile_order -fileset sources_1
```
I think this is a little better
```tcl
 set file_obj [get_files -of_objects [get_filesets sources_1] [list "*$file" "*/$registers"]]
```

I also got a lot of other errors when I tried to run the 'make fpga' command on the latest repo on master branch. 
For ex: 1) The line 27 in fpga/scripts/prologue.tcl was throwing a syntax error near '[' . I commented out this command from the tcl script since it is just something related to output prints
2) The line 91 in src/common _cells/src/lzc.sv was throwing syntax error near '. I looked at the latest version of this file in git and replaced that line with the latest copy to overcome the error. (The ariane soc was not getting the latest version of this file when i do git submodule and hence even a latest cloned version of ariane soc has this error)
Now I am getting this error that 'dm' not declared.

Can someone suggest me a way where I can easily generate the bitstream without having to resolve all these errors one by one ? 
PS: I know that there is a prebuilt bitstream in 4.2 release, but I want to create my own bitstream because I am planning on making some changes in the ariane core and generate bitstream for the changes. 

Thanking you in advance.

issues.title: About the fence instruction
issues.body:
Hi Guys,
  I noticed the current fence instruction implementation in Ariane flushes the L1 cache. Based on my understanding of the fence in the memory consistency model, it only needs to prevent the re-ordering of load-store instructions. I understand based on the current Ariane implementation, L1 cache needs to be flushed to remove some false data brought by the re-ordered loads.
  
  However, if I implement the fence instruction by preventing the load-store re-ordering, do I still need to flush the L1 cache or not? Based on the explanation of the fence instruction in the RISC-V manual, my implementation does not need to flush L1. However, I am afraid Ariane implements fence instruction for other reasons except for maintaining the memory-ordering as specified by the RISC-V manual. Any comments about this?

  Thanks for your help!

Cheers,

issues.title: uncached volatile writes not respected if write buffer not yet drained
issues.body: I have an encountered an issue where Ariane appears to return the value from the write buffer (or perhaps the cache?) in the case of a volatile uncached write, rather than the fresh value from IO memory. This is important for peripherals such as the UART where reads and writes to the same address go to different physical FIFOs. A possible workaround would be to offset the addresses of such peripherals when reading, taking advantage of don't care bits in the address. However this means changes to driver source code, which to some extent nullifies the benefit of emulating a standard interface in the first place. issuing a fence instruction in between the write and the read solves the problem at the expense of performance. I am using the master commit of Ariane with one change: DCACHE_SET_ASSOC=4

issues.title: Addressed are defined on 64 bits, which generates kgate overhead
issues.body:
In RISCV specification, two types of address are defined: physical and virtual address. Physical address is max 56 bits and virtual address is 39bit (sv39) or 48bits (sv48). 

In Ariane implementation, physical and virtual addresses are implemented on 64bits.
Address length dimensions a lot of functionalities, scoreboard or caches for instance. By implementing two RTL variables, PLEN (as physical length) and VLEN (as virtual length), address length becomes configurable. By setting PLEN=32 and VLEN=39, kgate reduction is about 40kgates.

I think it would be nice to integrate such a modification in main line to stick to the RISCV specification and reduce the gate count.

issues.title: Wrong Illegal instruction fault for compressed fld ft0, xxx(sp)
issues.body:
If a compressed instruction fld rd, xxx(sp) use ft0 as rd, currently Ariane will generate an illegal instruction fault, caused by the check at src/compressed_decoder.sv:205:
`if (instr_i[11:7] == 5'b0)  illegal_instr_o = 1'b1;`
However, the restriction that destination shouldn't be zero should only be applied to GPR.

Suggest to remove src/compressed_decoder.sv:205 to fix the fault.

labels.description: Issue will not be fixed

issues.body:
Hi, All

I am trying to work Ariane SoC with a SD controller, which has a DMA engine in it. The cache I use is write-through cache. I need to flush the D cache before DMA move SD blocks to DRAM.
As I found in #355 #339, the fence instruction do not really flush the write-through cache but only the write buffer. I think a better way is to disable the whole cache and re-enable it.
I try it on my FPGA with
```c
    __asm__ volatile("csrwi 0x701, 0x00");
    __asm__ volatile("csrwi 0x701, 0x01");
```
It seems work, but I am not sure if there is any potential risk. Any comment?

Thanks

issues.title: icache unknown when ISA extension "C" is enabled

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
Suffering from lots of
```
Offending '((|icache_dreq_o_data) !== 1'hx)'
```
Will this lead to some bad side effects?

And we can notice that this is caused when ISA extension "C" is enabled:
```
assign btb_prediction_shifted[0] = (serving_unaligned) ? btb_q : btb_prediction[0]
```
And we can see btb_q reset to 0:
```
btb_q <= '0
```
This looks wrong to me. Say, if we have code block booting from 0x8000_0000, why a default branch prediction result is not the vector entry or a reset vector? Given the fact that the address 0 may not be a ROM/RAM or may not be an initialized memory model.

In this case, 0 belongs to our SPINOR flash region.
It won't be initialized when we boot from ROM.

issues.title: Black box —Design 'unread'
ICache Refill in Case of an Exception

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
Hello, 

It seems here in the ICache that, if a request causes a TLB hit and a Cache miss, the ICache does not check the fetch exception before making a cache refill when it is in the TAG_CMP state:
https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/733a283798b07e7f97b483f1856b34d594e0f928/src/cache_subsystem/std_icache.sv#L271-L298

The fetch exception is only checked when the controller is in WAIT_ADDRESS_TRANSLATION before going to the REDO_REQ state. However, if the address is a TLB hit, and therefore the ICache controller does not go to the WAIT_ADDRESS_TRANSLATION, then the exception will be only forwarded to the core. This is generally not a problem unless it is a cache miss, which causes a cache line refill for an address which was not accessible to the currently running process. It may not be considered a bug but it may have security implications regarding side channel attacks. 

Is it the intended behavior of ICache? Am I missing something about this scenario?

Thanks in advance.
Mo Fadiheh

issues.title: Cache Controller

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
Hello, 

Consider the following scenario: the load_unit is in the IDLE state and req_port_i.data_gnt is zero. A request comes and as a result, the load unit goes to the WAIT_GNT state: 
https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/733a283798b07e7f97b483f1856b34d594e0f928/src/load_unit.sv#L102-L115

In the next clock cycle, req_port_o.data_req is high. Let's assume in this clock cycle the cache is available again, so the req_port_i.data_gnt goes high. At the same time, since the cache is available, the corresponding cache controller will go to the WAIT_TAG state in the clock cycle after that: 
https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/733a283798b07e7f97b483f1856b34d594e0f928/src/cache_subsystem/cache_ctrl.sv#L129-L163
If at the same clock cycle, the MMU returns an exception to the load unit for the requested address, the load unit will drop the request and goes back to IDLE, while its corresponding cache controller will be in WAIT_TAG, waiting for the physical address tag:
https://github.com/pulp-platform/ariane/blob/733a283798b07e7f97b483f1856b34d594e0f928/src/load_unit.sv#L241-L243

To make the long story short: what would happen if when the load unit is waiting for req_port_i.data_gnt, both data_gnt and exception arrive at the same time? Does it cause the cache controller to proceed with a canceled transaction? 
If so, then it can cause performance degradation and/or security implications.



Many thanks in advance.
Mo Fadiheh

issues.title: Changing PTE permission crashes kernel v5.7

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:Invalid
labels.description: Issue is not a valid problem or bug.

issues.body:
The following commit in 5.7-rc1 added STRICT_KERNEL_RWX support and broke Linux for openpiton/ariane core.

```
commit d27c3c90817e
Author: Zong Li <zong.li@sifive.com>
Date:   Tue Mar 10 00:55:41 2020 +0800

    riscv: add STRICT_KERNEL_RWX support
   
    The commit contains that make text section as non-writable, rodata
    section as read-only, and data section as non-executable.
   
    The init section should be changed to non-executable.
   
    Signed-off-by: Zong Li <zong.li@sifive.com>
    Signed-off-by: Palmer Dabbelt <palmerdabbelt@google.com>
```
Here is a hack to make it work (tested with master OpenSBI)
```
atish@jedi-01:~/workspace/linux$ git diff
```
```diff
diff --git a/arch/riscv/Kconfig b/arch/riscv/Kconfig
index 62f7bfeb709e..f176c29d4f27 100644
--- a/arch/riscv/Kconfig
+++ b/arch/riscv/Kconfig
@@ -60,7 +60,6 @@ config RISCV
        select ARCH_HAS_GIGANTIC_PAGE
        select ARCH_HAS_SET_DIRECT_MAP
        select ARCH_HAS_SET_MEMORY
-       select ARCH_HAS_STRICT_KERNEL_RWX
        select ARCH_WANT_HUGE_PMD_SHARE if 64BIT
        select SPARSEMEM_STATIC if 32BIT
        select ARCH_WANT_DEFAULT_TOPDOWN_MMAP_LAYOUT if MMU
diff --git a/arch/riscv/mm/pageattr.c b/arch/riscv/mm/pageattr.c
index 728759eb530a..7f8a2386af8c 100644
--- a/arch/riscv/mm/pageattr.c
+++ b/arch/riscv/mm/pageattr.c
@@ -116,10 +116,9 @@ static int __set_memory(unsigned long addr, int numpages, pgprot_t set_mask,
 
        if (!numpages)
                return 0;

        down_read(&init_mm.mmap_sem);
-       ret =  walk_page_range_novma(&init_mm, start, end, &pageattr_ops, NULL,
-                                    &masks);
+       //ret =  walk_page_range_novma(&init_mm, start, end, &pageattr_ops, NULL,
+       //                           &masks);
        up_read(&init_mm.mmap_sem);
 
        flush_tlb_kernel_range(start, end);
```
Here is my theory:
The above commented line changes the kernel init text+data pages to non-executable.
Kernel tries to flush all pages after that and makes a SBI call for sfence.vma. Once OpenSBI flushes
the entire TLB for all cores, it returns to the kernel. But kernel never resumes. My assumption is that
changing PTE entry attributes is not behaving correctly in ariane core. I would be happy to proven wrong and debug more in kernel and/or OpenSBI. However, I have spent couple of days analyzing the issue and this seems to most plausible theory till now.

issues.title: Co-simulation mismatch when reading stval CSR

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
### To reproduce
This failure happens when running one of the riscv-isa tests: `rv64ui-v-bltu`.

```c
make verilate DROMAJO=1
make run-dromajo-verilator BIN=$(RISCV)/riscv64-unknown-elf/share/riscv-tests/isa/rv64ui-v-bltu
```

### Details
According to ISA spec (from what I understood, I might be wrong), `stval` should be set to `0` unless core trapped because one of the following:
* hardware breakpoint
* instruction-fetch fault
* load or store address-misaligned fault
* access or page-fault exception
* illegal instruction trap

However, Ariane seems to set the value of `stval` when trapping due to `ecall` (which is not one of the above). It sets stval to `0x73` which is the machine code for ecall instruction. I suspect same maybe true for `mtval` csr.

Here is Dromajo trace (read comments):
```c
// commit hundreds of instructions
0 0x0000000000002e58 (0x00301a63)                        bne     zero, gp, pc + 20 
0 0x0000000000002e6c (0x00100513) x10 0x0000000000000001 li      a0, 1
0 0x0000000000002e70 (0x00000073)                        ecall
1 0xffffffffffe000c4 (0x14011173) x2  0xffffffffffe096d0 csrrw   sp, sscratch, sp <-- trap due to ecall
1 0xffffffffffe000c8 (0x00113423)                        sd      ra, 8(sp)
1 0xffffffffffe000cc (0x00313c23)                        sd      gp, 24(sp)
// commit more instructions
1 0xffffffffffe00148 (0x100022f3) x5  0x8000000200006000 csrr    t0, sstatus
1 0xffffffffffe0014c (0x10513023)                        sd      t0, 256(sp)
1 0xffffffffffe00150 (0x141022f3) x5  0x0000000000002e70 csrr    t0, sepc 
1 0xffffffffffe00154 (0x10513423)                        sd      t0, 264(sp)
1 0xffffffffffe00158 (0x143022f3) x5  0x0000000000000000 csrr    t0, stval // <-- reading stval
[error] EMU PC ffffffffffe00158, DUT PC ffffffffffe00158
[error] EMU INSN 143022f3, DUT INSN 143022f3
[error] EMU WDATA 0000000000000000, DUT WDATA 0000000000000073 << mismatch
[error] EMU MSTATUS 8000000a00006000, DUT MSTATUS 00000000
[error] DUT pending exception 8 pending interrupt -1

```

issues.body:
Dear Florian,
Congratulations with passing Ariane to Open HW Group!
Wish Ariane all the best!

I am motivated by the idea behind open source development and PULP project, so want to contribute to Ariane as a summer project. I want to start my journey by adding support for Bit Manipulation Extension. Nevertheless, first, I want to understand whether is it really necessary and useful for Ariane, or is it something extra that you don't want to consider for now? If B extension is something wanted, then is it possible to make some plan on contribution as for A extension support to make things clear, or could I be addressed to someone interested in this?) 

On the other hand, if B extension is not necessary for the present, then I am open to any new idea on contributions as a project. For example, is adding support for out of order executions interesting for Ariane? Or is there any other extension support or some architecture improvements that were planned/desired?

P.S. Basically, I have written an email to you too, but I am in worries whether is it got into spam or not. I am sorry if I am writing too much)

issues.body:
Hello, I have reviewed the code in wt_cache_subsystem.
It seems that the cache will be bypassed when the cache is not enable or the request goes to I/O space.
>> // noncacheable if request goes to I/O space, or if cache is disabled

>>>assign paddr_is_nc = (~cache_en_q) | (~ariane_pkg::is_inside_cacheable_regions(ArianeCfg, {{64-ICACHE_TAG_WIDTH{1'b0}}, cl_tag_d, {ICACHE_INDEX_WIDTH{1'b0}}}));

But when produce in FSM, it seems that only *cache_en_q* was used. 
>>>end else if ((|cl_hit && cache_en_q) || areq_i.fetch_exception.valid) begin

So when the request goes to I/O space, how does the cache work？

issues.body:
Hi there,
Coming back to simulations again, this time, I wanted to dump waveforms to `fst` instead of `vcd` during simulation, readily, to save memory. This is because of previous simulation results leading up to 20GB dumped vcd size. That was for simple `c=a+b` C source file with command `work-ver/Variane_testharness -v=dump.vcd $RISCV/riscv64-unknown-elf/bin/pk arithmetic.elf.` However, after converting that vcd file to `fst` with `vcd2fst`, filesize surprisingly reduced to 57.6MB. 

So, first of all, I tried to replace `--trace` with `--trace-fst` in Ariane Makefile according to Verilator manual and also tried to change `ariane_tb.cpp` for `VerilatedFstC` objects and `#include headers`, but things went unsuccessful. I think I am missing some important points. Could you help me with this extent? By the way, I have also tried to refer to [related RocketChip issue](https://github.com/chipsalliance/rocket-chip/issues/1689), however, that went unsuccessful too.

issues.title: Simulation Time is Different in QuestaSim
issues.body:
Dear Dr. Zaruba,

When I tried to use my own bash file to run Behavioral Simulation with QuestaSim, a strange phenomenon appeared. The simulation time of my script (245 264 250 ns) was more than twice longer than your Makefile ( 101 218 950 ns). 

Script_1. The vsim command from your Makefile is:
`vsim "+permissive" -t 1ns -coverage -classdebug -do " log -r /*; run -all;" "+jtag_rbb_enable=0" -lib work "+MAX_CYCLES=10000000" "+UVM_TESTNAME=core_test" "+BASEDIR=tmp/riscv-tests/build/isa/" "+UVM_NO_RELNOTES" "+UVM_VERBOSITY=LOW" -gblso /home/riscv-gnu-toolchain/lib/libfesvr.so -sv_lib work-dpi/ariane_dpi ariane_tb_optimized "+permissive-off" "++/home/riscv-gnu-toolchain/riscv64-unknown-elf/bin/pk" "++hello.elf" `

Script_2. The vsim command from my own bash file is:

`vsim "+permissive" -t 1ns -coverage -classdebug -suppress 7063 -suppress 7061 -suppress 2732 -suppress 3009 -do " log -r /*; run -all; " -lib work "+MAX_CYCLES=10000000" "+UVM_TESTNAME=core_test" "+BASEDIR=tmp/riscv-tests/build/isa/" "+UVM_NO_RELNOTES" "+UVM_VERBOSITY=LOW" -gblso /home/riscv-gnu-toolchain/lib/libfesvr.so -sv_lib work-dpi/ariane_dpi ariane_tb "+permissive-off" "++/home/riscv-gnu-toolchain/riscv64-unknown-elf/bin/pk" "++../../../ariane/hello.elf"`

Script_3. Your Makefile which runs in preload mode (Command: make sim preload=hello.elf)

`vsim "+permissive" -t 1ns -coverage -classdebug -do " log -r /*; run -all;" "+PRELOAD=hello.elf" "+jtag_rbb_enable=0" -lib work "+MAX_CYCLES=10000000" "+UVM_TESTNAME=core_test" "+BASEDIR=tmp/riscv-tests/build/isa/" "+UVM_NO_RELNOTES" "+UVM_VERBOSITY=LOW" -gblso /home/riscv-gnu-toolchain/lib/libfesvr.so -sv_lib work-dpi/ariane_dpi ariane_tb_optimized "+permissive-off" "++none" "++" 
`

The questions are:


> 1. Even though Script_1 and Script_2 is almost the same when running vsim, but why they have a great difference in behavioral simulation time?
> 2. It seems that preload memory has not effect on reducing total simulation time, when compare the simulation time result with Script_1 and Script_2, the Script_3  take the most time.  So why?
> 3. What may caused the shorter simulation time in Script_1?

issues.title: Idea: Change register type detection

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Enhancement
labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
Hey,

currently, the Ariane core detects from the operation if the register is a scalar or a floating-point one.

I would suggest instead a register for this task. The type of register is saved in a 2-bit value with the three values:

Constant
Scalar
Floating-Point

This would reduce the register from 7-bits to 2-bits. 
This is already done in the scoreboard to speed-up the register arbitration. 
https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/465bb209a02721cbaa6fa82a87df2eb464a39e60/src/scoreboard.sv#L70

What if this always done?

The decoder would be bigger but the register arbitration could be even faster. Only the type for the destination register is saved currently. With this change also the type for the source register would be saved. 
This would reduce the calculation if the destination and source register are of the same type. Only 4 bits then store all the necessary information. For FPGA this change is even better as most modern FPGA use LUTs with 4 or 6 inputs. This calculation can, therefore, be done with only one LUT.

The number of operations could even be reduced.  When the type of register is not saved in the operation itself. Different types of the same operation could be removed. For example, scalar add and floating-point add could be merged, as the Execution Unit is also determined by the decoder.

The integration of the constant type would also eliminate the need for the use_imm and use_zimm flags from the scoreboard entry.

This change would therefore only need 4 additional FFs per scoreboard entry.
2 FFs for the type of the destination register + 4 FFs for the two source registers - 2 FFs for the use_imm and use_zimm flag


When floating-point is not used the type could be changed to a 1-bit value:

Constant
Scalar

This meaning is then similar to the use_imm and use_zimm flags.

Would love to hear your opinions on this matter.

Best regards,
Raphael Klink

issues.title: A quick question about the XFVEC in Ariane

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Hi guys,

  In ariane, XFVEC represents whether the vectorial float extension (Xfvec) is enabled or not.  What's the relation between XFVEC and riscv vector instruction?

  In the decoder unit, it seems to me that the vectorial float extension is identified by using the "OpcodeOp" operation which actually represents an integer instruction. However, based on the riscv vector document, the vector instruction has the same opcode with the floating-point instructions. Any comments about this?

Many thanks
Xia

issues.title: Wrong exception tval for instruction fetch fault if instruction is crossing page boundary

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

issues.body:
When there is an instruction fetch causing page fault, according to riscv privileged instruction set document, mtval/stval "will ontain the virtual address of the portion of the instruction that caused the fault", but it seems that in the current implementation the PC is stored in the tval field. This causes hang when running some programs having a 32 bits instruction split across two pages; the fault appears to be in the first page while it should be on the second page.

The attachment is our current crafted binary that can trigger this hang in verilator and fpga running Linux, but successfully complete in QEMU.
[Test8.zip](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/files/4893666/Test8.zip)

For now we can work around this issue by disabling c extension during compilation of user level programs, which force all instructions to be 4 bytes aligned. We will try to make a PR for this issue.

issues.title: A corner case in std_icache when kill_s2 is asserted

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
Hello,

We find a corner case associated with BranchPrediction/std_icache/PTW when we try to boot the Linux OS with std_cache_subsystem. An error address translation result is returned by PTW，which makes the OS crash.

### Phenomenon
When _std_icache_ send address translation requests to MMU continuously，if the following conditions are met：
1. A branch mispredict  occurs in frontend, which will assert _kill_s1_、_kill_s2_ signal 
2. FSM of _std_icache_（_state_q_ in std_icache.sv）happens to be inside **TAG_CMP** stage when _kill_s2_=1 
3. The killed request and the following normal request are TBL miss

In this situation，MMU receives a back-to-back request and ask PTW to handle them. It seems that MMU treat the back-to-back requests as a single request due to the long process time in PTW. The first request is not killed actually, and the result is returned by MMU as the second request. which will make the Linux OS crash.

### Detail 
when _std_icache_ FSM jump to **TAG_CMP**, it asserts _areq_o.fetch_req_ and sends a translation request to MMU: 
https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/1b65b8865a505722b8bbbdd1a0e6dc959b28e166/src/cache_subsystem/std_icache.sv#L239
if _kill_s2_ is asserted at this state due to branch mispreditc in frontend:
https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/1b65b8865a505722b8bbbdd1a0e6dc959b28e166/src/frontend/frontend.sv#L244
https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/1b65b8865a505722b8bbbdd1a0e6dc959b28e166/src/frontend/frontend.sv#L247
FSM  in _std_icache_ will jump to **IDLE** to kill this request, but in fact this request has been sent to MMU: 
https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/1b65b8865a505722b8bbbdd1a0e6dc959b28e166/src/cache_subsystem/std_icache.sv#L381

If the instruction  queue is not empty, _dreq_i.req_ from frontend will keep asserted, FSM in _std_icache_ jumps to **TAG_CMP** again and sends another translation request. MMU receives a back to back request from _std_icache_ like this: 

> _icache_areq_i.fetch_req_ :    XXXX______/¯¯¯\\___/¯¯¯\\______XXXX
(the first one is the killed request and the second one is a normal request)

The killed request makes the FSM in PTW jumping from **IDLE** to **WAIT_GRANT**. As there is no mechanism in PTW to cancel a translation，when the second request come, PTW can not feel it and do something(e.g. update the _ptw_pptr_q_)，it is still in the translation process of the first request. The result of the killed request is returned, which will be treated as the result of the second request by _std_icache_.

So the gap is : _std_icache_ kills the first request and sends another request, but PTW does't kill the first one!

### Solution
Maybe **TAG_CMP** can be added in this code to wait PTW exit safely : 
https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/1b65b8865a505722b8bbbdd1a0e6dc959b28e166/src/cache_subsystem/std_icache.sv#L381

### Attachment
![std_cache_kill_s2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68343063/87636788-d829b580-c773-11ea-84b2-f6bdd8655ae0.jpg)

issues.title: Prefixing of module names and file names

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Enhancement
labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

labels.name: Status:New
labels.description: Newly created issue, nobody has looked at it yet.

issues.body:
In CV32E40P all module names and file names were prefixed with cv32e40p_ to avoid naming collisions at the chip level, see https://github.com/openhwgroup/cv32e40p/issues/276.

Can the same be done for all RTL files in CVA6 (I would propose a cva6_ prefix)? It would be particularly important for modules that have really generic names currently as e.g. 'alu', 'decoder'.

In CV32E40P the following naming style is used:

- Filename : cv32e40p_\<something\>.sv
- Module name: cv32e40p_\<something\>
- Instantiation: cv32e40p_\<something\> () \<something\>_i

issues.title: A corner case in std_dcache when executing AMO instruction

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
Hello,
 
We find a corner case associated with std_dcache and AMO/ld instruction, which makes Linux crash.
 
It is caused by the interface signal miss_req between cache_ctrl and miss_handler in std_nbdcache. When an amo instruction is committed, the following steps are executed in this case: 

1. An amo instruction is committed
2. flush_commit_o=1 in commit stage
3. req_port_o.kill_req=1 in load_unit, which is sent to to dcache
4. FSM in cache_ctrl.sv is reseted to IDLE,  miss_req sent to miss_handle is set to 0 

The problem is, miss_req is cleared a cycle later after req_port_o.kill_req is set to 1, if FSM in miss_handle happen to be inside IDLE, it will receive the killed miss_req signal, which will affect the following ld instruction and return a error result.
 
The instructions and waveform in this case are as below:

```
copy_process():
ffffffe000935b58:   4050b0ef            jal ra,ffffffe00094175c <recalc_sigpending>
ffffffe000935b5c:   10016073            csrsi   sstatus,2
ffffffe000935b60:   00023d03            ld  s10,0(tp) # 0 <__vdso_rt_sigreturn-0x800>
……
ffffffe00094175c <recalc_sigpending>:
…… 
ffffffe0009417a4:   60f2302f            amoand.d    zero,a5,(tp)
ffffffe0009417a8:   00813403            ld  s0,8(sp)
ffffffe0009417ac:   01010113            addi    sp,sp,16
ffffffe0009417b0:   00008067            ret
```
( the ffffffe0009417a4-amoand.d  is committed, ffffffe000935b60 should be killed, but it is not killed in miss_handle actually, ffffffe0009417a8 will use this error result returned by miss_handle later)

![std_dcache_miss_handle](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68343063/88249200-59ce9580-ccd6-11ea-8154-7f65f490de4d.jpg)

In order to solve this problem, I think miss_req should be cleared as soon as req_port_i.kill_req comes,  I add _miss_req_o = '0_ after line 405 in cache_ctrl.sv, it seems that it is ok and Linux can boot succesfully.
```
403 if (req_port_i.kill_req)   begin
404     state_d = IDLE;
405     req_port_o.data_rvalid = 1'b1;   
           miss_req_o = '0
406 end
```

issues.title: Do not use global imports of packages in the compilation unit scope unless necessary
issues.body: The use of global imports of packages (as for example done here https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/c57b275df595601cae85eed6b3b4d47639a6f510/src/ariane.sv#L25) should be avoided. For further justification please see the corresponding issue in CV32E40P https://github.com/openhwgroup/cv32e40p/issues/384. In CV32E40P all such imports were fixed in https://github.com/openhwgroup/cv32e40p/pull/389 and ideally the same is done in CVA6.

issues.title: Avoid using System Verilog defines in RTL code

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Enhancement
labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

labels.name: Status:New
labels.description: Newly created issue, nobody has looked at it yet.

issues.body:
The CVA6 uses the following defines (used in ifdef/ifndef statements):

- DROMAJO
- FIRESIM_TRACE
- FORMAL
- INSTR_TRACER_IF_SV
- PITON_ARIANE
- SYNTHESIS
- VERILATOR
- WT_DCACHE

Similar to the request made in https://github.com/openhwgroup/cv32e40p/issues/301 all such System Verilog defines should (ideally) be completely avoided in RTL code (and for example be replaced by localparam or parameter, avoided by a cleaner split between RTL and non-RTL code (in separate files), etc.). On CV32E40P all defines were avoided by rewrites performed in https://github.com/openhwgroup/cv32e40p/pull/389 (actually the define related to assertions is still there, but will soon be removed as well as assertions will move into seperate files outside of the RTL files). If for some reason defines will still be used, it would be cleaner if they use a uniform prefix (e.g. CVA6_)  to reduce the chance of conflicts with other RTL code.

issues.title: Question regarding custom extensions
issues.body:
According to the ISA listing in Table 24.1 of RISCV ISA Version 20191213, Page 129,
There are 4 opcodes for custom ISA extension, namely:
0001011
0101011
1011011
1111011
My question is: 
1) Are you using these custom opcodes for some Ariane specific functionailties? Or are there plans to do so? If I want to extend Ariane for my research work, would it be safe to use these opcodes?
2) Are you implementing the Compressed extension? Or are there plans? Is it safe to extend onto the 00-10 compression prefixes?

Thank you!

Zeran Zhu
University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, USA

issues.title: Wrong assert test in pmp
issues.body:
Hi,

I found an error  in the pmp_entry.sv file, at line 52 : `assert(addr_i < (conf_addr_i << 2) || addr_i >= (conf_addr_prev_i << 2))`
`||` needs to be replaced by `&&` to have a correct assert test. Indeed, with `||`, the assertion is always true.

Regards,
Emeric

issues.title: verilator: Arbitrary limitation on binary size

labels.name: Component:Tool-and-build
labels.description: For issues in the tool and build flow (e.g. Makefile, FuseSoc, etc.)

labels.name: Type:Enhancement
labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

labels.name: Status:New
labels.description: Newly created issue, nobody has looked at it yet.

issues.body:
Currently, for the Verilator simulation, there is an arbitrary limit on the binary size imposed here:
https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/8678fedda2d7f49784cc59eaccc3466776a98bdf/tb/ariane_tb.cpp#L322

The most elegant solution would be to load the entire binary size, probably one would need to modify the elf parser a bit to get the relevant information.

labels.name: Status:Resolved
labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Hello,

I am seeing an issue where `instruction_o.pc` will unexpectedly be set to 0 after `is_mispredict` is triggered. From what I see, `target_address` in `branch_unit.sv` gets set to 0, and triggers `is_mispredict` after being compared to the `branch_predict_i.predict_address`, which is 136. After `is_mispredict` is triggered, in `frontend.sv`, `npc_d` is set to `resolved_branch_i.target_address`, which is 0, which eventually causes `instruction_o.pc` to be set to 0. I previously tried the suggested workaround in #476 and #480, since the issue in #476 looked similar to the issue I was seeing, but the problem still duplicated. I included a screenshot of some relevant waveforms and of the relevant portion of bootrom's objectdump.





**Waveforms:**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70393977/91767884-777afe80-eba2-11ea-816b-98dde6a08efc.png)








**Relevant snippets from objectdump of bootrom:**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70393977/91768362-1acc1380-eba3-11ea-83a1-9e1ae8fa928d.png)
