issues.title: PMP Linux Issue
issues.body:
I've been having issues getting a Linux initramfs build to work using PMP. I believe it's something with the PMP code now, instead of a configuration issue. 

On both OpenPiton and ESP builds, I can get the Linux boot to reach the end before Init runs, and then it just hangs, on both builds. Usually this would be due to an incorrect initramfs build/image. I've tried adding a init that just executes a hello world program and that's not being executed.
The binary runs fine on the same cores without PMP. I've also used a different VM that has successful builds for another PMP Linux distribution, and it also failed. 

Here's where it gets stuck:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/60512105/94432149-520eef80-0164-11eb-85d5-dacb3791f725.png)

Now with ESP, when I remove the PLIC driver then I can overflow the buffer and it prints another panic for Init that I didn't see before. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/60512105/94432254-7b2f8000-0164-11eb-9d86-f5c31f811ca6.png)

That might be just related to the buffer overflow, I'm not sure. 

I can't get it to even spawn a terminal shell, which says it's not able to access the folder structure. Any help would be appreciated, thank you!

issues.title: PMP risc-v benchmark fails with page fault
DTM issue during negotiation time when XLEN=32bits

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
@zarubaf

I come back to you on a DTM subject, already discussed 1 month ago. My feeling is that DTM must be modified to support XLEN=32. 

When debug is activated and XLEN=32, I get an exception. During the negotiation phase, the SimDTM module challenges the DTM to know which is the size of the microprocessor. First SimDTM command tries to ask for 128bits transaction, second command asks for 64bits. If the two commands are not supported, SimDTM understands it is 32bits.

The first debug command received by DTM is: 0x00421008, size=3’b100 (128bits)
  The DTM answers with  
0x0000000000000300 ebreak 
 because the 128bits is not supported

The second command received is : 0x00321008, size=3’b011 (64bits)
  The DTM answer with the following sequence of instructions
0x0000000000000300  j       pc + 0x38
0x0000000000000338  csrw    unknown_7b3, a0
0x000000000000033c  auipc   a0, 0x0
0x0000000000000340  srli    a0, a0, 12
0x0000000000000344  slli    a0, a0, 12
0x0000000000000348  sd      s0, 896(a0)
As sd is not implemented in rv32, exception occurs

To my mind the second command should not be supported by DTM and DTM should be modified. I would be please to know you feeling about it. In the case you confirm it, I could submit a PR.

issues.title: MMU Performance Issue

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
I wanted to see if there have been any findings on the MMU for Ariane in regards to slower than normal operation. It's hard to characterize what normal operation is, but I have 2 other RISC-V processors with PMP that conduct some benchmarks along with Ariane. 

All 3 are testing the page table walker and verifying the virtual and physical memory. The other 2 are running at around the same cycle count within + or - 1 second within each other (I'm leaving out the actual cycle count for brevity). For Ariane, it's taking an additional 60 seconds (at 50MHz) on top of the time it takes the other 2 processors to do the same code for the PTW/TLB. I'm not entirely sure how to go about debugging something like this, but thought I would bring it up in case someone else has seen similar findings.

issues.title: AXI user signals in axi_node_intf_wrap

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Status:Resolved
labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
I noticed an issue with the `axi_node_intf_wrap` module instantiated as `i_axi_xbar`in the verilator model `ariane_testharness.sv`.
I expanded the axi user port in the `.axi_req_o ( axi_ariane_req      ),` signal coming from the ariane module to 134 bits to send additional information to one of the axi modules as part of the AW and AR bus. I also updated the `src/util/axi_*.sv` files to not set the user signals to 0.
However, it turns out the signal isn't propagated properly for the AR bus, whereas it is working mostly fine for AW.
I traced the signals and it seems that the culprit is the `i_axi_xbar instance` of `axi_node_intf_wrap`.
The screenshot shows the axi signals coming from the ariane module and entering the slave interface of the i_axi_xbar instance and the output of the 9 master interfaces. The signal is propagated properly for the AW port but not for the AR port

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/51908919/97084727-5a4e3380-1619-11eb-9bb7-56537df6f498.png)

This happens primarily with the ariane_testharness.sv, thus the Verilator model. I didn't confirm it for what's put on the FPGA, but since the ariane_xilinx.sv file uses a similarily named `axi_node_wrap_with_slices` I suspect a similar issue there.

I opened an issue here since the axi_node repo seems to be archives, so a possible solution for cva6 would be to transition to the succeeding module

issues.title: Tag width for caches
issues.body:
Hello,

I think there is an issue with the cache tag width in ariane_pkg. Indeed,

`ICACHE_TAG_WIDTH = riscv:PLEN - ICACHE_INDEX_WIDTH` must be `ICACHE_TAG_WIDTH = riscv:PLEN - ICACHE_INDEX_WIDTH - ICACHE_OFFSET_WIDTH` with `ICACHE_OFFSET_WIDTH = c$log2(ICACHE_LINE_WIDTH/8)` and 

`DCACHE_TAG_WIDTH = riscv:PLEN - DCACHE_INDEX_WIDTH` must be `DCACHE_TAG_WIDTH = riscv:PLEN - DCACHE_INDEX_WIDTH - DCACHE_OFFSET_WIDTH` with `DCACHE_OFFSET_WIDTH =c$ log2(ICACHE_LINE_WIDTH/8)`

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CPU_cache#Cache_entry_structure

Is it an oversight or is it intentional?

If it's an omission, I can do a PR to fix it.

Emeric

issues.title: No response from interconnect when adding master
issues.body:
Hello,

For the sake of achieving Direct Memory Access, I have created a small test module that reads a single memory address (`0xBC000000`) every 100 ms. This module is connected as master on the interconnect in the same way that the Ariane core is connected (using a `req_t` and `resp_t` connected to an `axi_master_connect`).

When trying to read a DRAM address, a response never arrives (`r_valid` never becomes high). I assumed the problem was in my test module, but when I change the address to one inside the bootrom instead of the DRAM, the response arrives correctly. To further inspect the issue, I have added debug probes to the AXI signals of both my own module and the DRAM. This results in the following waveforms:

Request in the test module:
![axi_req](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9934566/101696829-ff608680-3a76-11eb-8daf-3f05a1c65c07.png)

Request to the DRAM:
![axi_req_dram](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9934566/101696946-39318d00-3a77-11eb-83a2-28715466928f.png)

Response from the DRAM:
![axi_resp_dram](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9934566/101696993-4b133000-3a77-11eb-8905-16bc0d8e1254.png)

So the request arrives correctly at the DRAM, and the response is correctly returned to the interconnect. However, this result never propagates back to the test module.

issues.title: Debugging with Verilator, OpenOCD and GDB
issues.body:
I'm trying to connect to Verilator simulation from GDB. However, simulation finishes before OpenOCD connects to simulation executable and opens a new GDB port:

In the first terminal window I run:

`$ ./work-ver/Variane_testharness --rbb-port=38000 ~/Desktop/riscv-tests/benchmarks/dhrystone.riscv`

In the second terminal window I run:

`$ openocd --command 'gdb_port 0' --command 'tcl_port disabled' --command 'telnet_port disabled' -f ariane.cfg`

Here is my OpenOCD config file:

```
interface remote_bitbang
remote_bitbang_host localhost
remote_bitbang_port 38000

set _CHIPNAME riscv
jtag newtap $_CHIPNAME cpu -irlen 5

set _TARGETNAME $_CHIPNAME.cpu
target create $_TARGETNAME riscv -chain-position $_TARGETNAME -coreid 0

gdb_report_data_abort enable
gdb_report_register_access_error enable

riscv set_reset_timeout_sec 120
riscv set_command_timeout_sec 120

# prefer to use sba for system bus access                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
riscv set_prefer_sba off

# Try enabling address translation (only works for newer versions)                                                                                                                                                                                                              
if { [catch {riscv set_enable_virtual on} ] } {
    echo "Warning: This version of OpenOCD does not support address translation. To debug on virtual addresses, please update to the latest version." }

init
halt
echo "Ready for Remote Connections"
```

I think compiling the program with -ggdb option should be sufficient. Is there anyone who encountered this issue before?

issues.title: Processor stalling at atomic instructions
issues.body:
Hello, 

I am simulating atomic instructions on baremetal ariane. But, the processor is getting stuck at the atomic instruction and does not simulate anything else once it starts executing atomic instructions. 

I looked into the issue and figured out a few things: 
1) This is happening with all atomic instructions other than atomic load and store. 
2) This only happens when the value in the rs1 register is zero. 
3) I observed that the atomic instruction reaches the commit stage module but does not get committed since the amo_resp_i.ack signal doesnt go high. 

I am attaching the C program for amoxor and corresponding log files. Please help me fix this issue. 

Thanking you in advance
[atomic_instruction_issue.zip](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/files/5832085/atomic_instruction_issue.zip)

issues.body:
I believe the instruction for obtaining the required toolchain in the [Getting Statted](https://github.com/MikeOpenHWGroup/cva6#getting-started) of the README are out of date.  According to [riscv-gnu-toolchain #174](https://github.com/riscv/riscv-gnu-toolchain/issues/174#issuecomment-508962471):
> riscv-tools no longer includes a toolchain. You must build a riscv toolchain before you can build riscv-tools.

It would be a good idea to update the README accordingly.

issues.title: SRAM question, potential [BUG]

labels.name: Component:Verif
labels.description: For issues in the verification environment or test cases (e.g. for testbench, C code, etc.)

labels.name: Status:Resolved
labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Due to observation by me and a colleague (Iasonas Mastorakis), the input be_i of SRAM module is referred to **bit enable**. Although, the input coming from TAG_CMP module, be_ram, is referred to **byte enable**. Because of that, simulation of the behavioural SRAM leads to 'Z values on the most of MS bits. In this way, it is impossible to write the whole cache line in SRAM. 
Please confirm the potentiality of this bug.

Greetings

issues.title: user program not loading correctly using questa sim
issues.body:
Hi,

I am trying to run this test "rv64ui-p-sraw" in simulation. The test finishes successfully, but after comparing the .dump with the trace_log, I realized that the CPU did not even read the user program from the DRAM location: 80000000. It seems that the user program was not loaded at all in the DRAM.

Here is the commandline that I use:
make sim elf-bin=tmp/riscv-tests/build/isa/rv64ui-p-sraw batch-mode=1 

Here is a snippet of the trace log output:
    5490ns      267 M 0000000000010000 0 00100413 li             s0, 1                 s0  :0000000000000001
    5590ns      272 M 0000000000010004 0 01f41413 slli           s0, s0, 0x1f          s0  :0000000080000000 s0  :0000000000000001
    5690ns      277 M 0000000000010008 0 f1402573 csrr           a0, mhartid           a0  :0000000000000000
    5790ns      282 M 000000000001000c 0 00000597 auipc          a1, 0x0               a1  :000000000001000c
    5890ns      287 M 0000000000010010 0 07458593 addi           a1, a1, 116           a1  :0000000000010080 a1  :000000000001000c
    5990ns      292 M 0000000000010014 1 00040067 jalr           x0, s0, 0             s0  :0000000080000000
**_**_Exception @      6190, PC: 0000000080000000, Cause: Illegal Instruction_**,_** 
				tval: 0000000000000000
    6390ns      312 M 0000000000010040 0 f1402573 csrr           a0, mhartid           a0  :0000000000000000
    6490ns      317 M 0000000000010044 0 00000597 auipc          a1, 0x0               a1  :0000000000010044
    6590ns      322 M 0000000000010048 0 03c58593 addi           a1, a1, 60            a1  :0000000000010080 a1  :0000000000010044

It shows that while executing the bootrom, when PC=80000000, it  results in an illegal instruction(as above), instead of jumping to the reset vector instruction.

Here is a snippet of the .dump, which I expected:
Disassembly of section .text.init:

0000000080000000 <_start>:
    80000000:	04c0006f          	j	8000004c <reset_vector>

0000000080000004 <trap_vector>:
    80000004:	34202f73          	csrr	t5,mcause
    80000008:	00800f93          	li	t6,8
    8000000c:	03ff0a63          	beq	t5,t6,80000040 <write_tohost>
    80000010:	00900f93          	li	t6,9
    80000014:	03ff0663          	beq	t5,t6,80000040 <write_tohost>
    80000018:	00b00f93          	li	t6,11
    8000001c:	03ff0263          	beq	t5,t6,80000040 <write_tohost>
    80000020:	80000f17          	auipc	t5,0x80000
    80000024:	fe0f0f13          	addi	t5,t5,-32 # 0 <_start-0x80000000>
    80000028:	000f0463          	beqz	t5,80000030 <trap_vector+0x2c>
    8000002c:	000f0067          	jr	t5
    80000030:	34202f73          	csrr	t5,mcause
    80000034:	000f5463          	bgez	t5,8000003c <handle_exception>

Any help is appreciated! 

Thanks,
Jatan P.

issues.title: Describe CVA6 for write-through and write-back cache versions

labels.name: Component:Doc
labels.description: For issues in the Documentation (e.g. for README.md files)

labels.name: Status:Resolved
labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Enhancement
labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

issues.body:
In #602, there was a conversation like this:

> Is the list of files in the manifest complete?
>> Looks okay for the write-through cache version. Of course, the write-back cache needs different files.

AFAICT, the ability to compile CVA6 for either  write-through and write-back cache versions is not described in the User Manual.  The User Manual should be updated to explain:
1. How to compile the CVA6 for  write-through and write-back cache versions.
2. Theory of operation for the write-through cache controller.
3. Theory of operation for the write-back cache controller.

labels.name: Component:RTL

labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.description: Newly created issue, nobody has looked at it yet.

issues.body:
In mmu.sv, line 247, there's a mixture of vaddr and PLEN, which causes a misalignment in `tval`
```icache_areq_o.fetch_exception = {riscv::INSTR_ACCESS_FAULT, {{riscv::XLEN-riscv::PLEN{1'b0}}, icache_areq_i.fetch_vaddr}, 1'b1};```
Same for line 258
```else icache_areq_o.fetch_exception = {riscv::INSTR_ACCESS_FAULT, {{riscv::XLEN-riscv::VLEN{1'b0}}, ptw_bad_paddr}, 1'b1};```

issues.title: Unable to synthesize modified Ariane design - 'ariane_peripherals'
issues.body:
Hi,

I am trying to make some modifications in the Ariane design.
I want to output some of Ariane's internal signals on the Genesys II board leds.
After doing the necessary changes in the RTL, I went ahead and tried to `make fpga` but I keep getting an error about the `ariane_peripherals` module.

After reading the RTL files imported during synthesis in the "add_source.tcl", I see that the **ariane_periherals** module is imported twice, once from the file `/Ariane/fpga/src/ariane_peripherals_xilinx.sv` and another one from the file `/Ariane/tb/ariane_peripherals.sv`.

The interface of the **ariane_peripherals** module that corresponds to the one instantiated inside the top file `ariane_xilinx.sv` is the one provided in the `/Ariane/fpga/src/ariane_peripherals_xilinx.sv` file. However, it seems that the `/Ariane/tb/ariane_peripherals.sv` is used in practice, as the modifications I make to the interface of **ariane_peripherals** (adding ports) in both **ariane_peripherals_xilinx.sv** and **ariane_xilinx.sv** files, don't seem to work:
`ERROR: [Synth 8-349] instance 'i_ariane_peripherals' of module 'ariane_peripherals' passed 32 connections, but takes just 25 [/PATHNAME/Ariane/fpga/src/ariane_xilinx.sv:543]`

I tried removing completely the`/Ariane/tb/ariane_peripherals.sv` file from the sourced ones, but I got the following error:
`ERROR: [Synth 8-439] module 'ariane_peripherals' not found [/Projects/Proj/ariane/Ariane/fpga/src/ariane_xilinx.sv:541]`

It seems that the peripherals module inside **ariane_peripherals_xilinx.sv**, is not recognized at all.

Is there a reason for sourcing the same module from 2 different files during Synthesis?

Thank you in advance for your response and time.

Kind regards,
Nassos

issues.title: Can not compile CVA6 for Verilator, ReadMe still errant

labels.name: Status:Resolved
labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Hello, 

The readme file does NOT work, and I am not precisely sure what is failing.  Seems a missing include. Whereas the tool chains themselves are poorly documented, I followed the method proffered by @JeanRochCoulon in _Out of date instructions in the README #591_, which eventually takes you to following: https://github.com/ThalesGroup/cva6-tools/tree/master/toolchain.  Once that is done, Which BTW has issues in terms of accurately describing how to use and assumes things it should not, then you end up with tools installed at `$INSTALL_DIR`, which you then have to reset your `$RISCV` to point to, and then things like `$RISCV/bin/riscv-none-elf-gcc` etc are available.  Great, first significantly major hurdle over.

**Next, we do the install** 
`git clone https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6.git`
`git submodule update --init --recursive`

**Then we do a make, and it fails...**
`make verilate`

**After a bit, we get this error - which I've seen consistently no matter how /what tools are installed:**

/usr/bin/perl /usr/local/share/verilator/bin/verilator_includer -DVL_INCLUDE_OPT=include Variane_testharness.cpp Variane_testharness___024unit.cpp Variane_testharness_uart_bus.cpp Variane_testharness_REG_BUS__A20_D20.cpp Variane_testharness_AXI_BUS__A40_AB40_AC5_AD1.cpp Variane_testharness__Dpi.cpp > Variane_testharness__ALLfast.cpp

 #include <fesvr/dtm.h>

 #include <fesvr/dtm.h>
          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~

It seems the `#include <fesvr/dtm.h>` is not able to be found.  At this point I am completely stuck, and there seems no google out of it ;)

issues.title: GDB debugging with JTAG on Genesys 2
Improper hierarchical path is defined in macro MAIN_MEM(P) (ariane_tb.sv) when dromajo is used.

labels.name: Component:Tool-and-build
labels.description: For issues in the tool and build flow (e.g. Makefile, FuseSoc, etc.)

labels.name: Status:Wont-fix
labels.description: Issue will not be fixed

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Currently macro MAIN_MEM (tb/ariane_tb.sv) is defined as follows:

`define MAIN_MEM(P) dut.i_sram.gen_cut[0].**gen_mem**.i_ram.Mem_DP[(``P``)]

but when dromajo is used then path should be as follows:

`define MAIN_MEM(P) dut.i_sram.gen_cut[0].**gen_dromajo**.i_ram.Mem_DP[(``P``)]


Maybe both options should be defined under `ifdef as presented below:

`ifdef DROMAJO
`define MAIN_MEM(P) dut.i_sram.gen_cut[0].gen_dromajo.i_ram.Mem_DP[(``P``)]
`else
`define MAIN_MEM(P) dut.i_sram.gen_cut[0].gen_mem.i_ram.Mem_DP[(``P``)]
`endif

issues.title: How to evaluate a benchmark correctly?
issues.body:
Hello,

I have an application, and I would like to evaluate how many cycles each instruction takes.

For that, I built the Verilator simulator, and I also compiled the application to run on top of `pk`.
From the traces I got, I see that many cycles are spent in Debug Mode ( https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/issues/601 , https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/issues/157 ).

So to get more accurate statistics, I do the following:
- I only consider the cycles where the application is in User Mode and only the instructions belonging to a given address range.
- I modified `src/ariane.sv`, so I can report, for each executed instruction, the number of cycles spent on it, not just the cycle where it occurred.
- I sum up all the numbers of cycles for each instruction

So my questions are:
- Is this methodology correct to get consistent statistics? Should I include those cycles spent in Debug Mode?
- How is the memory (DRAM, L1D, L1I) accesses modeled? 
  It is mentioned [here](https://cva6.readthedocs.io/en/latest/intro.html?highlight=Two%20cycle%20memory%20access#scope-and-purpose) that the data cache (or DRAM) has a latency of 1 cycle whereas the instruction cache has a 3-cycle latency; however, I could not locate these parameters in the repository, can you please tell me where they are if they are parametrizable?

Thanks a lot!

Best regards,

I have a fully functional riscv-toolchain and I am using verilator 4.201 on Debian 10.

Would really appreciate some help.

issues.title: wt dcache tx transimit function

labels.name: Component:Doc
labels.description: For issues in the Documentation (e.g. for README.md files)

labels.name: Status:Wont-fix
labels.description: Issue will not be fixed

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Hi I am using cva core to study cache coherence. Can anyone help me with an understanding problem.

While wt cache write buffer use tx to transmit, the logic it use to split disaligned data is really odd to me. Here is my point of view. If If the valid area is 0000_0111, it wont match any of the given cases in toSize64 function, so it will marked as individual. What will happen is, instead of split into 0000_0011 and 0000_0100, it will split into 0000_0001, 0000_0010, 0000_0100. Because neither 0000_0111 nor 0000_0110 match any unique cases.

issues.title: Replacement Policy in TLB's

labels.name: Component:Doc
labels.description: For issues in the Documentation (e.g. for README.md files)

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Status:Wont-fix
labels.description: Issue will not be fixed

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Below is an example of how FIFO replacement policy works for 8 Entry TLB:
The replacement policy has a simple counter of 3 bit which wraps upon overflow
i.e. 111 -> 000 thus getting a FIFO logic

```
Ways  :   0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
Valid :   0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0  FIFO points to Way 0
          ^
```

After 5 entries in TLB
```
Ways  :   0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
Valid :   1 1 1 1 1 0 0 0  FIFO points to Way 5
                    ^
```

now an ASID based flushed invalidated `Way 2` and `Way 3`
```
Ways  :   0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
Valid :   1 1 0 0 1 0 0 0  FIFO points to Way 5
                    ^
```
Now consider 4 more entries are made in TLB,
the fourth entry will evict a valid entry from way 0
even though there was an empty location at `Way 2` and `Way 3`.
```
Ways  :   0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
Valid :   1 1 0 0 1 1 1 1  FIFO points to Way 0
          ^ 
          |-Evict
```
This makes the replacement policy inefficient.

> *What I want to point is that the way selected for replacement should be a
> function of both replacement policy logic and Valid bits (empty entries).*

Replacement policy logic should be looked up only when all entries are filled in
fully associative TLB. We should first fill the empty entries (holes) and then
perform eviction.


This is my understanding of how a replacement policy works (maybe wrong).
So when i saw the code of TLB for ariane core at https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/src/tlb.sv#L226

The replacement signal `replace_en` does not depend upon the `tags_q.valid`
Thus creating the same in-efficiency issues regardless of replacement policy used
(tree based pseudo replacement).

Did i infer it correctly and if this is a design decision then what was the
drawback in using valid bits as part of replacement logic ?

Could someone give me more insight about this TODO? I think write buffer should be disabled because you are not flushing the WT_DCACHE on fences and amos with the rl annotation. If write buffers are enabled and not flushed on the fences and release points, how do you ensure the global ordering of memory accesses across these boundaries?

Thank you very much!

I wonder how this value is calculated in CVA6.

issues.body:
**i have a coprocessor i designed to do image processing as the image enters the cva6 core and by a software on it will be transfer the image to my coprocessor then do the processing which had been chosen by custom instruction in the core then give the image back to the core again to present the result of the processing ...

- so i want to ask how to make the software to run on the core?

- and the next question what is the suitable way to make the interface between co-processor and the core to send and get the data how to design this interace or bus??**

issues.title: Mounting Linux image in QuestaSim Simulation
issues.body:
Dear Dr. Zaruba and project contributors,

I am in the process of simulating Ariane with the Linux image mounted on it, in QuestaSim. From what I see in previous threads [[1]](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/issues/6#issuecomment-367030272) [[2]](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/issues/314) this is possible.

I have a couple of questions that I would greatly appreciate if someone can help me with:

a) You are mentioning a time of ~1.5 days [[3]](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/issues/42) in order to mount the image in simulation. Is this time with preloading or not? From what I have seen, there is an option to preload the Linux image in the memory. Is `make sim preload=vmlinux` the correct command to preload the Linux image in the memory and simulate it (vmlinux image being inside the `./cva6` folder)? 

b) What do I expect to see inside the `transcript` file that is generated? Do I expect to see all the booting sequence that I witness when booting in Linux using the FPGA? 
Until now, I have run the above mentioned command and I got the following inside the `transcript` file after ~2 days of running:
```
# ----------------------------------------------------------------
# UVM-1.1d
# (C) 2007-2013 Mentor Graphics Corporation
# (C) 2007-2013 Cadence Design Systems, Inc.
# (C) 2006-2013 Synopsys, Inc.
# (C) 2011-2013 Cypress Semiconductor Corp.
# ----------------------------------------------------------------
# ** Warning: NUMERIC_STD."=": metavalue detected, returning FALSE
#    Time: 0 ns  Iteration: 0  Instance: /ariane_tb/dut/i_ariane_peripherals/gen_uart/i_apb_uart/UART_RXFF
# ** Warning: NUMERIC_STD."=": metavalue detected, returning FALSE
#    Time: 0 ns  Iteration: 0  Instance: /ariane_tb/dut/i_ariane_peripherals/gen_uart/i_apb_uart/UART_TXFF
# UVM_INFO tb/ariane_tb.sv(129) @ 0: reporter [Core Test] Preloading ELF: vmlinux
# [TRACER] Output filename is: trace_hart_0.log
# UVM_INFO tb/ariane_tb.sv(138) @ 80: reporter [Core Test] Loading Address: 0000000000000000, Length: 0000000000019074
# UVM_INFO tb/ariane_tb.sv(138) @ 80: reporter [Core Test] Loading Address: 000000000001a000, Length: 0000000000b767ec
```

c) From your experience, is it possible to run such a simulation at a post-synthesis/post-implementation stage or is it only possible with the pre-synthesis RTL?

d) Is it possible in simulation to run a simple C program when the Linux image has completely booted?

I would greatly appreciate any response on the above questions as it is the first time trying to go through such a complex simulation mechanism.

Thank you in advance for your responses and time!

Kind regards,
Nassos

issues.title: code point 0x120000f3 with rd=1 retires as sfence.vma

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:New
labels.description: Newly created issue, nobody has looked at it yet.

issues.body:
This is a collateral finding on the RTL from OneSpin processor app formal analysis.
According to the RISC-V privileged ISA, only "0001001 rs2 rs1 000 00000 1110011" should decode as sfence.vma (Sail has the decoding as 0b0001001 @ rs2 @ rs1 @ 0b000 @ 0b00000 @ 0b1110011). However, cva6 seems to ignore the 5 bits of the RD fiels leading to, for example, 0x120000f3 being decoded as sfence.vma with rd=1 and actually retiring as no exception flag is set in the scoreboard and thus, it is flushed in conjunction with the instruction retired counter incrementing.
Expected behavior would be to flag this as illegal.
![sfence](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45827187/115229680-a0410b80-a113-11eb-8c30-d9009e5a667e.png)
See attached waveform - the problematic instruction word is fetched at -3, issued at -2, makes it to slot 0 of the scoreboard at -1, the scoreboard entry gets marked as valid at -1 and in this chycle, the scoreboard is flushed while the sfence commits and leads to the instruction retired counter being incremented from 0 to 1.
Note that I cut the 8-bit counters in the cashes to get to a quick counterexample, but that should not be related to the reported issue which looks like a decoder issue. Git hash of examined RTL is 6000e32.

issues.title: Crash a Bare metal test CVA6-RISC-V assembly hello world
issues.body:
After implementing cva6 on the VCU118 FPGA board, I did a baremetal test to display "hello world". For the compilation I used RISC-V GNU Compiler Toolchain ..... to load the binary and start its execution I used openOCD and GDB.

The program crashes ....... After the step-by-step display of the executed assembler instructions, the processor only executes the first five assembler instructions,  **This crash can be caused by what ?** 

I dont understand why the **PC** of the third instruction is **not aligned**(0x8000008**a**)?

## Section assembly 
```.D
Déassemblage de la section .init :

0000000080000080 <_start>:
    80000080:	00004197          	auipc	gp,0x4
    80000084:	9e818193          	addi	gp,gp,-1560 # 80003a68 <__global_pointer$>

issues.body:
I don't understand the meaning of DCACHE_NUM_WORDS , I did some calculations based on the standard configuration of the Dcache and I found that it is a  8 way set-associative cache, each set contains 8 Cache Lines with each line is 128 bits. Each CL is separated into to words of 64bits stored in two different banks ( bank0 contains word0 of each CL ,   bank1 contains word1 of each CL) .But when I calculated DCACHE_NUM_WORDS I found (2^8=256) . Moreover, Is the Dcache write through? because I found in the description of some src files (wt_dcache_wbuffer and wt_dcache_mem) that the used blocks are for wb cache .

Another question: Is there any available detailed documentation to understand the microarchitecture of cva6 (implemented protocols and design choices) ?

issues.title: Adding DDR4 & DataWidthConverter_512_64 for VCU118  adaptation
issues.body:
### I added the DDR4 and the DATA_WIDTH_CONVERTER_512_64 but I get incoherent results:

The cache requests 128bits of data through the DATA_WIDTH_CONVERTER_512_64. DDR4 generates a first frame equivalent to the base address (base @) which the DATA_WIDTH_CONVERTER reads the first 64-bit word. Then the DDR4, generates a first frame equivalent to (base @ + 512) of which the DATA_WIDTH_CONVERTER reads the second word of 64bits.

I want to retrieve the second word from the first frame in order to retrieve contiguous 128bits in memory, I don’t know why DDR4 provides me with the second 512-bit frame that I did not request .

Do you have any idea on the source of the problem?

labels.description: CVA6-related SW tasks

issues.body:
Hi,

I have the following question regarding the Linux image running on Ariane.
When a user process accidentally tries to access an address inside the kernel address space (allocated or not to an LKM), the kernel crashes displaying the following message:

```
[   62.181919] user_process1.o[113]: unhandled signal 11 code 0x1 at 0xffffffd00400b400
[   62.181919] user_process1.o[113]: unhandled signal 11 code 0x1 at 0xffffffd00400b400
[   62.193285] CPU: 0 PID: 113 Comm: user_process1.o Tainted: G           O      5.1.0-rc7 #12
[   62.193285] CPU: 0 PID: 113 Comm: user_process1.o Tainted: G           O      5.1.0-rc7 #12
[   62.210756] sepc: 00000000000101da ra : 00000000000101cc sp : 0000003fff9b2d60
[   62.210756] sepc: 00000000000101da ra : 00000000000101cc sp : 0000003fff9b2d60
[   62.225360]  gp : 0000000000022970 tp : 0000001555752ec0 t0 : 00000000000102ec
[   62.225360]  gp : 0000000000022970 tp : 0000001555752ec0 t0 : 00000000000102ec
[   62.240059]  t1 : 0000000000001000 t2 : ffffffffffffffff s0 : 0000003fff9b2d80
[   62.240059]  t1 : 0000000000001000 t2 : ffffffffffffffff s0 : 0000003fff9b2d80
[   62.255185]  s1 : 00000000000a1600 a0 : 0000000000000001 a1 : 0000003fff9b1920
[   62.255185]  s1 : 00000000000a1600 a0 : 0000000000000001 a1 : 0000003fff9b1920
[   62.269881]  a2 : 0000000000000000 a3 : 0000003fff9b17f8 a4 : 00000000aaaabbbb
[   62.269881]  a2 : 0000000000000000 a3 : 0000003fff9b17f8 a4 : 00000000aaaabbbb
[   62.284808]  a5 : ffffffd00400b400 a6 : 0000003fff9b1920 a7 : ffffffffffffff9f
[   62.284808]  a5 : ffffffd00400b400 a6 : 0000003fff9b1920 a7 : ffffffffffffff9f
[   62.299712]  s2 : 000000000009a6bb s3 : 000000000008ab20 s4 : 00000000000a1640
[   62.299712]  s2 : 000000000009a6bb s3 : 000000000008ab20 s4 : 00000000000a1640
[   62.314628]  s5 : 0000000000000008 s6 : 0000001555752ed0 s7 : 000000000000000a
[   62.314628]  s5 : 0000000000000008 s6 : 0000001555752ed0 s7 : 000000000000000a
[   62.329533]  s8 : 0000000000000000 s9 : 0000000000089be8 s10: 00000000000a1600
[   62.329533]  s8 : 0000000000000000 s9 : 0000000000089be8 s10: 00000000000a1600
[   62.344442]  s11: 00000000000a3045 t3 : 0fffffffffffffff t4 : 0000000000000019
[   62.344442]  s11: 00000000000a3045 t3 : 0fffffffffffffff t4 : 0000000000000019
[   62.359487]  t5 : 0000000000000009 t6 : ffffffffffffffbf
[   62.359487]  t5 : 0000000000000009 t6 : ffffffffffffffbf
[   62.371406] sstatus: 8000000200006020 sbadaddr: ffffffd00400b400 scause: 000000000000000f
[   62.371406] sstatus: 8000000200006020 sbadaddr: ffffffd00400b400 scause: 000000000000000f
```

In the above example the user process accessed the kernel space address `0xffffffd00400b400`, which caused the kernel to crash with an error code `0xf` that corresponds to a `STORE_PAGE_FAULT`. It is obvious that a user process should not have access to the kernel address space, however from my knowledge I was expecting for the program/user process to crash instead of the whole kernel.

Can I safely assume that this behavior is attributed to the Linux image and is the expected?

Thank you in advance for your responses and time.

Kind regards,
Nassos

labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.description: For general questions

labels.name: Status:New
labels.description: Newly created issue, nobody has looked at it yet.

issues.body:
Hi Team,

As per riscv-privileged spec "All of these counters have 64-bit precision on RV32, RV64, and RV128." In CVA6 performance counter width is tied to XLEN value. According to the spec, the perf counters width should be 64 bits.

-Pranay

issues.title: Cache_ctrl.sv

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:New
labels.description: Newly created issue, nobody has looked at it yet.

issues.body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/discussions/671
Originally posted by **Simonlovald** May 28, 2021 Hello, I am currently working on my master thesis using the old cache_ctrl as a case study. My topic is formal verification, and I am trying to automatize the generation of a complete set of properties for the design. While writing constraints for the design, I noticed some states that I am not really able to understand why they are needed. I can't see a scenario where there is no tag_valid-input and no gnt, coming from state IDLE, which then makes the cache_ctrl enter the WAIT_GNT? here: https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/485662f0c9a315e084c5e18db49b4ea4a7503dfe/src/cache_subsystem/cache_ctrl.sv#L258-L268 From my understanding both the load-unit and the ptw will always send a tag-valid in the next clock cycle after receiving data_gnt from the cache_ctrl. So how can the cache_ctrl possibly ever enter WAIT_GNT? Only situation I can imagine, is if the load-unit got an exception when receiving the data_gnt, https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/485662f0c9a315e084c5e18db49b4ea4a7503dfe/src/load_unit.sv#L244-L247 but then the load-cache_ctrl will be stuck in WAIT_GNT/WAIT_TAG, as there is no way the load-unit can receive another data_gnt while the cache_ctrl is waiting for a tag_valid and therefore will never issue a tag_valid... Sounds like a deadlock to me. I am guessing this is related to issue #430 I am grateful for any help regarding the understanding of this design. Thank you in advance.

issues.title: PMP and G value
Width of scounteren,mcounteren and mvendorid CSR to be 32
issues.body:
As per the spec scounteren (12'h106) ,mcounteren (12'h306) and mvendorid(12'hF11) CSR width need to be of 32 bit wide with all different XLEN size. 
In current implementation these CSRs takes width as per XLEN. In case XLEN is 32, these CSRs are 32 bit wide, how ever when XLEN is 64, the listed CSRs are also goes 64 bit wide.

issues.title: Steps to completely disable the data cache

labels.name: Component:Doc
labels.description: For issues in the Documentation (e.g. for README.md files)

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
As agreed in the meeting, these are the steps that you need to do, to be able to completely disable the data cache.

Firstly : You need a parameter to generate caches in the ariane_pck.sv.
https://github.com/E-Poulin/cva6-softcore-contest/blob/d491e67ae04ad4e492a3ae6f5af401e8d77955b4/include/ariane_pkg.sv#L428

Secondly : You need conditions (if generate) to generate or not the caches, in the wt_cache_subsystem (for the WT cache), and in the std_cache_subsystem (for the WB cache).
https://github.com/E-Poulin/cva6-softcore-contest/blob/d491e67ae04ad4e492a3ae6f5af401e8d77955b4/src/cache_subsystem/wt_cache_subsystem.sv#L116-L165

Thirdly : You need to direct the core requests from the LSU to the Axi bus (and then to the main memory).  I did not finish this part because of lack of time.
https://github.com/E-Poulin/cva6-softcore-contest/blob/d491e67ae04ad4e492a3ae6f5af401e8d77955b4/src/cache_subsystem/wt_cache_subsystem.sv#L194-L215

Regards,
Emeric

issues.title: Incorrect implementation of the FENCE.I instruction detection logic

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

issues.body:
Location:  cva6/src/decoder.sv (https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/src/decoder.sv), line 220 to 240.

Details: The RISC-V specification states that the hardware implementations should ignore the imm, rs1, and rs2 fields of the FENCE.I instruction. However, the cv6 implementation expects a hardcoded value of zero in all these fields. Hence, it is flagging valid FENCE.I instructions with non-zero values in these fields as illegal instructions. 

For example, the SPIKE successfully executes the FENCE.I instructions with non-zero imm field but cv6 does not.

issues.title: Some illegal instructions are capable of being executed

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

issues.body:
Location:  cva6/src/decoder.sv (https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/src/decoder.sv), line 153 to 162.

Details: The if statement in the default case is missing else. Hence the illegal_instr will not be set even for instructions not meeting the if condition. 

Thus any illegal instruction of the format 64’hxxx00073 (‘x’ is dont-care) will not be detected as illegal by Ariane.

issues.title: Failure to detect cache coherency violation.

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
Location: cva6/src/cache_subsystem (https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/tree/master/src/cache_subsystem).

Details: According to the RISC-V specification, when the instruction memory is modified, the software should handle the cache coherency using FENCE.I instruction. If the input program modifies the instruction memory but does not use a FENCE.I instruction, there is a mismatch in the trace log of Ariane and spike. Ariane executes the instructions from the old instruction memory whereas spike executes the instruction from the newly updated instruction memory.

issues.title: PMP Configuration Registers pmpcgf1 and pmpcfg3 for CV32A6 is not present for CSR Read
issues.body:
As per specification for 32 Bit CPU we should have CSR_PMPCFG0, CSR_PMPCFG1, CSR_PMPCFG2 and CSR_PMPCFG3. How ever for 64 bit CPU, it requires only CSR_PMPCFG0 and CSR_PMPCFG2 [ For CSR Read this is present in RTL].
For CSR Read CSR_PMPCFG1 and CSR_PMPCFG3 is not present which is required for 32 Bit CPU.

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

issues.body:
Let's say I have an execution of rdcycle (accessing the `cycle` register, addr 0xc00) in M-mode.

            if ((riscv::priv_lvl_t'(priv_lvl_o & csr_addr.csr_decode.priv_lvl) != csr_addr.csr_decode.priv_lvl)) begin
                privilege_violation = 1'b1;

In this case 
`csr_addr.csr_decode.priv_lvl = PRIV_LVL_U` (2'b00)
and 
`priv_lvl_o = PRIV_LVL_M` (2'b11)
resulting in a privilege violation.

Is this the expected behaviour or is M-mode expected to access all registers?

issues.title: Top-level configuration structures for CVA6

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Status:Wont-fix
labels.description: Issue will not be fixed

labels.name: Type:Enhancement
labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

issues.body:
The [CVA6 Specification](https://docs.google.com/document/d/11rsoO5WKraMCraSpnsVqmt4hJaCcDG0zq7LTWdXVkf0/edit#heading=h.3qxt8brmoedo) identifies four "golden configurations":
1. cv32a6_imacf_sv32_fpga
2. cv32a6_imac_sv32_fpga
3. cv64a6_imacfd_sv39
4. cv32a6_imac_sv0

Each of these configurations should be easily implemented via a single parameter structure passed to the [top-level module of CVA6](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/ariane.sv#L27).  Currently, there is only one top-level configuration, called [ArianeDefaultConfig](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/include/ariane_pkg.sv#L58).  Ideally, there should be a set of four such configuration structures, one per "golden configurations" as described in the Specification.

labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

labels.name: Status:In Progress
labels.description: Work on this issue has started, but is not complete.

issues.body:
This issue is related to #743.

The [ariane_cfg_t](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/include/ariane_pkg.sv#L36) struct does not "contain" all the parameters needed to fully define all CVA6 configurations.  (There is even a [TODO](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/include/ariane_pkg.sv#L130) comment in the code about it.)

This issue can be closed when _all_ parameters required to implement any of the "golden configurations" mentioned in #743 are added to `ariane_cfg_t`.

issues.body: This issue is related to #743 and #744, and exists to ensure that the golden configurations and their associated parameters in [ariane_cfg_t](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/include/ariane_pkg.sv#L36) are described in the CVA6 User Manual.  A good example of this can be found in the [Integration](https://cv32e40p.readthedocs.io/en/latest/integration/#parameters) chapter of the CV32E40P user manual.

```

Loop Signal: i_axi_xbar.axi_node_i._RESP_BLOCK_GEN[0].RESP_BLOCK.rready_i
Loop Signal: i_axi_xbar.axi_node_i._RESP_BLOCK_GEN[0].RESP_BLOCK.BR_ALLOC.rready_i
Loop Signal: i_axi_xbar.axi_node_i._RESP_BLOCK_GEN[0].RESP_BLOCK.BR_ALLOC.error_gnt_o
Loop Signal: i_axi_xbar.axi_node_i._RESP_BLOCK_GEN[0].RESP_BLOCK.AR_ADDR_DEC.error_gnt_i
Loop Signal: i_axi_xbar.axi_node_i._RESP_BLOCK_GEN[0].RESP_BLOCK.AR_ADDR_DEC.arready_int
Loop Signal: i_axi_xbar.axi_node_i._RESP_BLOCK_GEN[0].RESP_BLOCK.AR_ADDR_DEC.arready_o
Loop Signal: i_axi_xbar.axi_node_i._RESP_BLOCK_GEN[0].RESP_BLOCK.arready_o
Loop Signal: i_ariane.i_cache_subsystem.i_adapter.i_axi_shim.rd_gnt_o
Loop Signal: i_ariane.i_cache_subsystem.i_adapter.arb_gnt
Loop Signal: i_ariane.i_cache_subsystem.i_adapter.invalidate
Loop Signal: i_ariane.i_cache_subsystem.i_adapter.axi_rd_rdy
```

In the first two cases, the combinational loop occurs in axi2mem.sv, where the slave.w_ready signal is sensitized to the value of slave.ar_valid and slave.aw_valid respectively. slave.w_ready is then routed through the atomics module which has ar_valid and aw_valid sensitized to w_ready, creating a loop.

In the third case, a similar event occurs between slave[0].r_ready and the error_gnt_o signal.


Has anyone else ran into this issue? How should I resolve it?

[formal_design.rpt.txt](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/files/7269932/formal_design.rpt.txt)

issues.title: Verilator doesn't stdout Hello CVA6!
issues.body:
I've been trying to set up the verilator workflow with the comments from the recent pull request #740 in a blank VM with Ubuntu 20.04 (until now I was using QuestaSim and the Genesys II). When executing `work-ver/Variane_testharness $RISCV/riscv64-unknown-elf/bin/pk hello.elf` after compiling with `riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc hello.c -o hello.elf`, it seems to run normally but in the end there is no "Hello CVA6!" output to stdout. I have tested the generated .elf on the Genesys II from my previous working flow and it seems to work fine. Any suggestions on what I could be missing? Thanks!

issues.body:
@zarubaf  Current documentation says
"
Generating a Bitstream
To generate the FPGA bitstream (and memory configuration) yourself for the Genesys II board run:
make fpga
"
With reorg and changes in riscv_pkg for XLEN, " make fpga " does not work for 32 bit. Just "make fpga" make 64 bit CPU.

However "make fpga variant=32" may help generating Bitstream ( .mcs/.bit) for 32 bit CPU. Documentation changes may help a lot. ( Thanks @JeanRochCoulon for helping with suggession)

issues.title: Expected behavior with an erroneous test
issues.body:
I was trying to see what should be the output of the simulation with an erroneous test. Steps:
1. Modify a `riscv-test` and insert an error. For instance, in `rv64ui/and.S`:
```asm
  TEST_RR_OP( 2, and, 0x0f000f00, 0xff00ff00, 0xdeadbeef );
```
2. Recompile the `riscv-tests` suite
3. Execute the Verilator simulation
```bash
$ ./work-ver/Variane_testharness tmp/riscv-tests/build/isa/rv64ui-p-and
This emulator compiled with JTAG Remote Bitbang client. To enable, use +jtag_rbb_enable=1.
Listening on port 42003

- /home/pascal/cva6-experiments/cva6/corev_apu/tb/rvfi_tracer.sv:57: Verilog $finish
- /home/pascal/cva6-experiments/cva6/corev_apu/tb/rvfi_tracer.sv:57: Second verilog $finish, exiting
```
I was expecting to get an error related to my step 1 (yes, I made sure to use my freshly compiled binary). Am I doing something wrong?

issues.body:
Hello,

I have already attached an AXI Slave component on the AXI Crossbar, and communicated to it from the OS through the Kernel Driver. For this purpose, I assigned an address let's say 0x5000_0000 to this AXI Slave IP. 

My problem now is that If I want to connect several AXI Slaves (as part of another module) (for example 8 AXI Slave Slaves) on the AXI Cross bar which is the best solution? The easiest and probably not professional way is that to extend number of slave ports of the AXI Crossbar. But, since I am a perfectionism, I intend to extend the AXI Crossbar with just one AXI Slave port, then re-construct the AXI Slave Components on it through an "AXI DMUX". 

PROBLEM: Since in the ariane_soc_pkg.sv I have only one extended slave base address, how the Kernel Driver distinguishes the AXI Slave ports of the AXI DMUX? (The setup is as follows):

 
![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38837310/144589991-de119896-bdc3-4972-8bd7-768b791ad376.jpg)

In the above figure the bottom path (IP1), consider user software wants to communicate to the AXI Slave port with address 0x5000_000. Since this address is set into the ariane.dts, and is mmaped by the Kernel Driver, it can be easily recognized by the system. However, I am not confident (have not the knowledge) that how to use AXI DMUX and distinguish connected Slave Components from the user software (also in ariane.dts). 

I eagerly look forward in someone who has the key of this question! 
Saluti,
FKHM

issues.title: Cached regions other than the first one ignored by std_nbdcache
issues.body:
Even though the `ariane_pkg::ariane_cfg_t` structure gives the appearance of support for multiple cached regions in the address map through its `NrCachedRegionRules` element,  only _one_ region's `CachedRegionAddrBase ` is passed down to the `std_nbdcache` instantiation [here](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/360c34af6900a4a3653a4e5c9002b74dd0261acb/core/cache_subsystem/std_cache_subsystem.sv#L83). The other regions appear to be ignored completely.

Additionally, the `CachedRegionLength` is _not_ passed down, even just for the single region, which means that all addresses beyond that region's `CachedRegionAddrBase` are treated as cacheable, with no upper-bound to the cacheable region.

issues.title: Trap Handling: PC set to Other Adress than Specified by MTVEC

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Bug
labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

issues.body:
Hi,

we are formally verifying the processors behavior upon privilege increase. Therefore we are checking if a user-level process sets the PC to the correct address when a trap to machine or supervisor mode is executed.

According to the RISCV-ISA (Document Version 20211203) section 3.1.7 (page 29) and 4.1.2 (page 66) the *mtvec* and *stvec* registers specify  how the corresponding address is calculated. Both registers consist of a BASE-field and a MODE-field. The MODE for *mtvec* and *stvec* can be set independently from each other to either *direct* or *vectored*. That means upon a trap to machine mode 
- PC is set to BASE of *mtvec* if the MODE of *mtvec* is *direct* 
- PC is set to BASE + 4 * cause if MODE is *vectored* and it is an interrupt. 

Similarly traps into supervisor mode are handled according to the settings of BASE and MODE in *stvec*.

When formally verifying this behavior on CVA6 we get a counterexample showing a behavior that does not comply with the ISA: A user-level process executes an interrupt and sets the PC to BASE + 4 * cause. However, the MODE of *mtvec* is set to *direct*.

The reason for that can be found in lines 981-998 or more precisely in line 996 of the csr_regfile.sv: 
https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/e748564dd880d68a9b0bde7e1a92c48c75823391/core/csr_regfile.sv#L981-L998
Whenever **one** MODE, the MODE of *mtvec* or the MODE of *stvec*, is set to *vectored* and it is an interrupt, the address calculation for the PC is done in *vectored* mode. Is this a bug or am I missing something here?

Thanks and best regards,
Anna

issues.title: Cannot view memory address contents through OpenOCD GDB debugging (FPGA emulation)

labels.name: Component:Tool-and-build
labels.description: For issues in the tool and build flow (e.g. Makefile, FuseSoc, etc.)

labels.name: Status:Resolved
labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Hi,
I am new to OpenOCD and debugging through FPGA emulation. So, pardon if any of the following seem trivial. 

I am using the Digilent 2 board for emulation purposes. I built my openocd from riscv-openocd fork. I have a working Linux OS installed on my target. I followed the instructions provided on readme to open a terminal for OpenOCD using:
`openocd -f ariane.cfg`
This seems to be working fine with the output log being:

```
`Open On-Chip Debugger 0.11.0+dev-02217-g52ca5d198 (2022-01-31-13:19)
Licensed under GNU GPL v2
For bug reports, read
	http://openocd.org/doc/doxygen/bugs.html
none separate

DEPRECATED! use 'adapter speed' not 'adapter_khz'
DEPRECATED! use 'adapter driver' not 'interface'
Warn : Interface already configured, ignoring
DEPRECATED! use 'ftdi vid_pid' not 'ftdi_vid_pid'
DEPRECATED! use 'ftdi channel' not 'ftdi_channel'
DEPRECATED! use 'ftdi layout_init' not 'ftdi_layout_init'
DEPRECATED! use 'ftdi layout_signal' not 'ftdi_layout_signal'
Info : auto-selecting first available session transport "jtag". To override use 'transport select <transport>'.
Warn : `riscv set_prefer_sba` is deprecated. Please use `riscv set_mem_access` instead.
Info : clock speed 1000 kHz
Info : JTAG tap: riscv.cpu tap/device found: 0x00000001 (mfg: 0x000 (<invalid>), part: 0x0000, ver: 0x0)
Info : [riscv.cpu] datacount=2 progbufsize=8
Info : Examined RISC-V core; found 1 harts
Info :  hart 0: XLEN=64, misa=0x800000000014112d
[riscv.cpu] Target successfully examined.
Info : starting gdb server for riscv.cpu on 3333
Info : Listening on port 3333 for gdb connections
Ready for Remote Connections
Info : Listening on port 6666 for tcl connections
Info : Listening on port 4444 for telnet connections`
```
Then I opened a second terminal to open gdb. I generated the .elf file of a simple Hello World program by compiling with the the riscv64-unknonw-elf-gcc. Then I established connection with the remote host. This is probably where the problem starts as I can see there's some packet error encountered although I am not sure why.

```
Copyright (C) 2019 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>
This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it.
There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.
Type "show copying" and "show warranty" for details.
This GDB was configured as "--host=x86_64-linux-gnu --target=riscv64-unknown-elf".
Type "show configuration" for configuration details.
For bug reporting instructions, please see:
<https://github.com/sifive/freedom-tools/issues>.
Find the GDB manual and other documentation resources online at:
    <http://www.gnu.org/software/gdb/documentation/>.

For help, type "help".
Type "apropos word" to search for commands related to "word"...
Reading symbols from /home/hasan/Desktop/hello.elf...
(gdb) target remote localhost:3333
Remote debugging using localhost:3333
0xffffffe0006930e4 in ?? ()
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
```
Next, I load the program using `load`. However, I see that the program is starting loading into the address 0x100b0 which I believe should not be the case (it should start at 0x800000). But it still loads the program successfully:
```
(gdb) load
Loading section .text, size 0x260c lma 0x100b0
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Loading section .rodata, size 0x18 lma 0x126c0
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Loading section .eh_frame, size 0x4 lma 0x136d8
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Loading section .init_array, size 0x10 lma 0x136e0
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Loading section .fini_array, size 0x8 lma 0x136f0
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Loading section .data, size 0xf58 lma 0x136f8
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Loading section .sdata, size 0x40 lma 0x14650
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Start address 0x100c6, load size 13784
Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Transfer rate: 286 bytes/sec, 1969 bytes/write.
```
Meanwhile, I get this error message on the first terminal:
```
Error: Timed out after 120s waiting for busy to go low (abstractcs=0x8001002). Increase the timeout with riscv set_command_timeout_sec.
Error: Abstract command ended in error 'busy' (abstractcs=0x8001102)
Error: Timed out after 120s waiting for busy to go low (abstractcs=0x8001102). Increase the timeout with riscv set_command_timeout_sec.
Error: Unsupported register (enum gdb_regno)(8)
Error: Abstract command ended in error 'busy' (abstractcs=0x8001102)
Error: Timed out after 120s waiting for busy to go low (abstractcs=0x8001102). Increase the timeout with riscv set_command_timeout_sec.
Error: Unsupported register (enum gdb_regno)(8)
```
I have tried to set the timeout from telnet using `riscv set_command_timeout_sec 300`. This time I did not get the unsupported register or timeout errors on the OpenOCD terminal (it still shows packet error on gdb terminal though).  

After the program is loaded, when I try to single step through the program using `si` it gets stuck at "Ignoring packet error, continuing" and nothing shows up. I also tried to read memory addresses using 
```
(gdb) x/i 0x100b0
   0x100b0 <register_fini>:	Ignoring packet error, continuing...
Reply contains invalid hex digit 116
```
This same error message (Reply contains invalid hex digit) shows up for other memory addresses as well.

What am I doing wrong? To the best of my understanding, the problem lies with the elf file loading since it's loading at address 0x100b0 instead of 0x80000. Is there a different process for generating the elf file in FPGA emulation other than the process I followed? Also, why do I get these other errors? How do I get rid of them? Any help is much appreciated, thanks.

of store bytes, a missed branch, a taken branch to a load, and a page fault taken on that load.  The 
CVA6 trace stops following the first store byte.  I'm not sure if this is the last instruction retired from the

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Type:Enhancement
labels.description: For feature requests and enhancements

labels.name: Status:New
labels.description: Newly created issue, nobody has looked at it yet.

issues.body:
In `ariane_pkg.sv` parameter `MMU_PRESENT` is always set. It should not be the case since cv32a6_imac_sv0 configuration does not 
 have MMU.

https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/e4b48a794b0229eeb9264a6b3f459c86545d1d85/core/include/ariane_pkg.sv#L625

I recommend to make this parameter depends on which cva6 config package we use. 

- ` cv32a6_imac_sv0_config_pkg.sv`
-  `cv32a6_imac_sv32_config_pkg.sv`
- `cv32a6_imafc_sv32_config_pkg.sv`
- `cv64a6_imafc_sv39_config_pkg.sv`

I believe we should also modify parameter like SV_MODE, SV, VLEN ? accordingly.
https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/e4b48a794b0229eeb9264a6b3f459c86545d1d85/core/include/riscv_pkg.sv#L48-L49

Some more RTL may or may not need changes if MMU is disabled but I didn't look into that very deeply.

issues.title: Debug Specification for CVA6

labels.name: Component:Doc
labels.description: For issues in the Documentation (e.g. for README.md files)

labels.name: Status:Resolved
labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
According to their respective User Manuals, both the CV32E40X and CV32E40S have adopted Version1.0.0-STABLE of the RISC-V Debug Support specification.  As this has not yet been ratified by RISC-V International, the current version of the CVA6 specification points to version 0.13.2 as this is the most up-to-date _ratified_ version of the RISC-V Debug spec.

There is always a natural tension between the desire to be as up-to-date as possible and the need to maintain compliance to a ratified spec.   @Silabs-ArjanB, can you comment on why the CV32E40X/S decided to go with v1.0.0?   Thanks.

issues.title: How to run User-Space code ?
issues.body:
Hi,

I try to run the code by the step in following:

```
echo '
#include <stdio.h>

int main(int argc, char const *argv[]) {
    printf("Hello CVA6!\\n");
    return 0;
}' > hello.c
riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc hello.c -o hello.elf
```
```
make verilate
work-ver/Variane_testharness $RISCV/riscv64-unknown-elf/bin/pk hello.elf
```
and it didn't print "Hello CVA6!" in terminal,  it only output the information like below:
```
This emulator compiled with JTAG Remote Bitbang client. To enable, use +jtag_rbb_enable=1.
Listening on port 36061
bbl loader
- /home/N26091526/cva6/corev_apu/tb/rvfi_tracer.sv:60: Verilog $finish
- /home/N26091526/cva6/corev_apu/tb/rvfi_tracer.sv:61: Verilog $finish
- /home/N26091526/cva6/corev_apu/tb/rvfi_tracer.sv:61: Second verilog $finish, exiting
```
I try to use spike to simulate the C code, it can print "Hello CVA6!"  successfully.
```
bbl loader
Hello CVA6!
```
Can anyone help me to resolve this problem?

Hello @Moschn and @zarubaf

I am working on the write through cache you designed.

I have some questions:
-  I would like to reduce the number of way to 2 instead of 8 in default configuration today, I encounter a problem with lsfr.sv module which doesn't allow to have less than 4 for LfsrWidth parameter. According to you, is it possible to modify lsfr module in order it to be able to manage a LfsrWidth parameter equal to 2?
- I wonder if there is a link betwen ariane_pkg::DCACHE_SET_ASSOC value and DCACHE_INDEX_WIDTH which are both equals to 8 in default configuration or if these values are independants?

Regards,

Sébastien

issues.title: Clarification on ECALL instruction

labels.name: Component:Verif
labels.description: For issues in the verification environment or test cases (e.g. for testbench, C code, etc.)

labels.name: Status:Resolved
labels.description: Issue has been resolved, but closure is pending on git merge and/or issuer confirmation

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Dear All,
I have a question regarding the handling of the ECALL instruction (32h73): In the rvfi_tracer this instruction leads to the direct finish of the simulation (https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/corev_apu/tb/rvfi_tracer.sv#L60). Can you explain why this is the case? Is this just not handled at this point in time?
I am currently using a little bit older commit (44a89b9cd408b869fb4ed2c0cec35e1561588e37), as the later ones result in the issue raised in #800. Running `make run-asm-tests` will run the rv64ui-v-addi test which results in the test not passing (no "SUCCESS" is being printed).
I raise this issue, as one can comment out the finish statements in the tracer and the program finishes correctly. However, a synthesized version of the core will get stuck at this instruction. The synthesized core I have will run the benchmarks and other compiled programs (and most isa tests) correctly, but some of them exhibit this problem.

I would be really happy to hear back from you

Kind regards
Christian

issues.title: fpu_valid_o in issue_stage.sv
issues.body: I was learning about how Fpnew is integrated into the Ariane core and wanted to make sure how its handshake interface (ready/valid protocol) is being dealt with. When I traced the Fpnew's ready/valid signals from bottom-up, I realized that the valid signal was supposed to be generated in the issue stage. However, no wires or registers are assigned to fpu_valid_o within the issue_stage module. This should cause fpu_valid_o being undefined and hence affecting the functionality of Fpnew? Or did I misunderstand sth?

~~~
git clone https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6.git
cd cva6
git submodule update --init --recursive

mkdir tmp

echo '
#include <stdio.h>

int main(int argc, char const *argv[]) {
    printf("Hello CVA6!\\n");
    return 0;
}' > hello.c

riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc hello.c -o hello.elf

make sim elf-bin=$RISCV/riscv64-unknown-elf/bin/pk target-options=hello.elf batch-mode=1

issues.title: Debug Mode / Program Buffer Exception?
issues.body: Hi, I had a question on the functionality of debug mode in the core. Let me know if this is a more appropriate question for https://github.com/pulp-platform/riscv-dbg. When cva6 is in debug, running a program in the program buffer and encounters an exception, how does it communicate to the debug module to set cmderr? I was able to trace it back to here in the debug module: https://github.com/pulp-platform/riscv-dbg/blob/d83a5f9547bd04d4fce47b4c91cc03e502ab5607/src/dm_mem.sv#L257 https://github.com/pulp-platform/riscv-dbg/blob/d83a5f9547bd04d4fce47b4c91cc03e502ab5607/src/dm_mem.sv#L48 which corresponds to here: https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/c26bda3f7bd2291a8704f27a1088b9587e9b4c4b/corev_apu/tb/ariane_testharness.sv#L238 But then I was unable to trace that back past the AXI bus. Is there some logic in cva6 which is sending this debug req message when an exception occurs, or is the debug module somehow detecting by virtue of the sequence not successfully completing?

issues.title: Is it possible for CVA6 to be attacked by meltdown?

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Status:Wont-fix
labels.description: Issue will not be fixed

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
Hi, I try to implement the [meltdown attack](https://meltdownattack.com) on CVA6 but I have some problems.

The purpose of the [meltdown attack](https://meltdownattack.com) is to try to use the load instruction to access data with illegal permissions, and to leak the data through a cache-based side channel. Therefore, we must find a way to delay the processing of exceptions so that there is time to leak data with illegal permissions.

According to the document of CVA6, the architecture of CVA6 is in-order issue, OoO write back and in-order commit. And CVA6 only handles exceptions in the commit stage. So I think this architecture may have the opportunity to be threatened by [meltdown attack](https://meltdownattack.com).

Below is the simple assembly code segment I am trying to execute:

```
fdiv.s fa6, fa4, fa5                             // to delay the commit of the exception.
ld s1, 0(s1)                                     // load data with illegal permissions (will cause the exception)
add s3, s2, s1                                 
ld s2, 0(s3)                                     // leakage the data by cache based side channel
```
Since the execution time of the `fdiv.s` instruction is not long enough, the exception is committed first before the data is successfully leaked. I try to use other instructions like `div` to delay the commit of the exception, but the `add` instruction will not be issued by issue unit because the execution unit is occupied by `div` as shown below.

```
always_comb begin : unit_busy
        unique case (issue_instr_i.fu)
            NONE:
                fu_busy = 1'b0;
            ALU, CTRL_FLOW, CSR, MULT:
                fu_busy = ~flu_ready_i;
            FPU, FPU_VEC:
                fu_busy = ~fpu_ready_i;
            LOAD, STORE:
                fu_busy = ~lsu_ready_i;
            CVXIF:
                fu_busy = ~cvxif_ready_i;
            default:
                fu_busy = 1'b0;
        endcase
    end
```
Is there any other instruction whose execution time is longer than `fdiv.s`, and will not conflict with the resources of the `add` instruction and the `load`instruction ? Or are there other reasons why the CVA6 is not at risk from a meltdown attack?

issues.title: Redundant RTL in multiplier.sv file
issues.body:
Hi @zarubaf,

I was going through [multiplier.sv](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/2c3d0f741d5d7ce55b06181a417280bfae499583/core/multiplier.sv#L48) file and I noticed that the logic implemented in the following lines is not being used in entire module:

```
logic [riscv::XLEN*2-1:0] mult_result;
assign mult_result   = $signed({operand_a_i[riscv::XLEN-1] & sign_a, operand_a_i}) *
                                   $signed({operand_b_i[riscv::XLEN-1] & sign_b, operand_b_i});
```
Moreover, the RTL of the line [number#49](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/2c3d0f741d5d7ce55b06181a417280bfae499583/core/multiplier.sv#L49) is similar to the one in line [number#72](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/2c3d0f741d5d7ce55b06181a417280bfae499583/core/multiplier.sv#L72), as shown below:

```
assign mult_result_d   = $signed({operand_a_i[riscv::XLEN-1] & sign_a, operand_a_i}) *
                                       $signed({operand_b_i[riscv::XLEN-1] & sign_b, operand_b_i});
```

Is it redundant or it is written on purpose?

issues.title: Bypassing the cache - confused on physical address generation

labels.name: Component:RTL
labels.description: For issues in the RTL (e.g. for files in the rtl directory)

labels.name: Status:Wont-fix
labels.description: Issue will not be fixed

labels.name: Type:Question
labels.description: For general questions

issues.body:
I'm interested in bypassing the cache subsystem ([the data cache](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/cache_subsystem/wt_dcache.sv)) in an effort to communicate between the CPU and the main memory directly. However, I'm running into issues regarding the physical addressing between the two.

I'm having real difficulty understanding how the lower order bits of the CPU request's physical address need to be converted before being sent out to the AXI adapter (with the existing cache subsystem). I've collected instruction trace information of the CVA6 running a benchmark program, grouping the memory request type, the request from the [Load/Store unit](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/load_store_unit.sv), and the input to the AXI adapter (memory request). I can't make heads or tails of why (and how) the lower 4 bits change:

**request #, request type, cpu request physical address, memory request physical address**
_1,  sb, 800290bf   (...1111), 800290bf  (...1111)
2,    sb, 800290be  (...1110), 800290bd (...1101)
3,    sb, 800290bd  (...1101), 800290bb (...1011)
4,    sb, 800290bc  (...1100), 800290bc  (...1100)
5,    sb, 800290bb  (...1011), 800290b7 (...0111)
6,    sb, 800290ba  (...1010), 800290b8 (...1000)
7,    sb, 800290b9  (...1001), 800290be (...1110)
8,    sb, 800290b8  (...1000), 800290b4 (...0100)
9,    sb, 800290b7  (...0111), 800290b9 (...1001)
10, sb, 800290b6   (...0110), 800290b5 (...0101)
11, sb, 800290b5   (...0101), 800290ba (...1010)
12, sb, 800290b4   (...0100), 800290b6 (...0110)_
.. 

I think my confusion comes from not really understanding the byte addressing format of the CPU/AXI protocol. I've thought through many possibilities but am still unable to spot the pattern or the rationale behind the input/output addresses. 

I've tried going through CVA6's source code, investigating where the memory request physical addresses are generated or used to better understand the data transactions. For example, [here](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/cache_subsystem/wt_axi_adapter.sv#L142), where depending on the 3rd bit of the memory request's physical address, we rearrange the 32 bit data coming from the LSU. Or [here](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/cache_subsystem/wt_axi_adapter.sv#L185), where it seems that the last 3 bits of the physical address correspond to a write byte enable for the 64 bit AXI bus. Or [here](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/master/core/cache_subsystem/wt_dcache_wbuffer.sv#L178) where the write buffer sets the _paddr_ bits... that last one seemed promising, so I followed the _wbuffer_dirty_mux.wtag_ and _bdirty_off_ signals down the rabbit hole, but their assignment was a bit hard to follow as they are connected to the Round Robin arbiter and also a leading zero counter, which are connected to other signals, and so on...

I've attached a simulation result which illustrates the above store requests. 

To summarize, I'd really appreciate some guidance on how the physical addresses need to be set in order to properly bypass the cache. I'm getting rather lost within the code. Thank you so much! 

![memory_request_simulation](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67859416/165784608-8d715a38-22cf-4c6f-9cca-a243c5c846a1.png)

issues.title: [Bug Report] incorrect SFENCE.VMA decoder
issues.body:
Hi, we are currently doing some co-simulation with cva6 and spike, and we found the decoder has an incorrect behavior when meeting a sfence.vma with non-zero rd field.

According to the ISA Specification (Volume II: RISC-V Privileged Architectures V20211203 Page 152) for the SFENCE.VMA format, instr[11:7] should be 5'b00000. 

When modified instr[11:7] to 5'b00001. cva6 treats this instruction as SFENCE.VMA as well. No exception occurred. The implementation is missing a check for this field. 

https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/blob/44a89b9cd408b869fb4ed2c0cec35e1561588e37/core/decoder.sv#L152-L165

In the following test case, there is an invalid sfence.vma at 0x80000190, whose rd field is 1, cva6 execute it as normal instruction, while spike throws an excaption.
```
  [cva6] 532890ns    26637 M 000000008000018c 0 12000073 sfence.vma 
  [spike] core   0: 0x000000008000018c (0x12000073) sfence.vma zero, zero                         
  [cva6] 534950ns    26740 M 0000000080000190 0 120000f3 sfence.vma    
  [spike] core   0: 0x0000000080000190 (0x120000f3) unknown
  [spike] core   0: exception trap_illegal_instruction, epc 0x0000000080000190
  [spike] core   0:           tval 0x0000000000000000
```

[cva6-0.zip](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/files/8694534/cva6-0.zip)

> @LuminaDCIX helps reproduce the problem

labels.name: Component:RTL

labels.description: For bugs in the RTL, Documentation, Verification environment or Tool and Build system

issues.body:
Hi,
We found that cva6 allows LOAD instructions to load value from an address that is outside the DRAM space. According to RISC-V Unprivileged ISA V20190608, page 7, "if an instruction attempts to access memory at an inaccessible address, an exception is raised for the instruction. Vacant locations in the address space are never accessible". However, cva6 did not throw an exception for this case.
We have the triggering test case (.mem file), the RTL trace log, and the spike trace log attached below. We can see that we are trying to load from an address outside DRAM space to register x10 (lbu  a0, -302(sp)). CVA6 is not throwing any exception for this instruction whereas spike is throwing load access fault exception.

Is this a bug in cva6?
[bug_report.zip](https://github.com/openhwgroup/cva6/files/8749872/bug_report.zip)
